questions.text: A lady developed a skin reaction as shown in the image after using a hair dye. Which of the following chemicals is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This is most likely a case of hypersensitivity reaction caused by p-phenylenediamine (PPD), which is present in hair dyes.
Hair dyes such as PPD have the potential to cause contact dermatitis.
A patch test is recommended 24-48 hours before its usage either on the forearm or behind the ear. The appearance of any redness, blistering or swelling implies allergy.

questions.text: A female patient presented with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Option A,C,D-dietary triggers,antibiotic resistance and drug triggers are other factors that may result in non-responsiveness.
Option B-The next best step for a female patient with acne that is resistant to oral isotretinoin is to check for hyperandrogenism.
Hyperandrogenism usually manifests as hirsutism, acne, and/or androgenetic alopecia.
Acne that is persistent, moderate to severe, or late onset raises concern for PCOS or other causes of hyperandrogenism.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the clinical condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is a case of Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) which are benign, pigmented melanocytic nevi present at birth. They are most commonly brown, black, purplish or red, usually a palpable lesion with heterogeneous color and texture.Malignant melanoma is more commonly associated with a congenital melanocytic nevus.

questions.text: There is a 0.3 cm ulcerated nodule on nasolabial fold. Diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Option A-Basal cell carcinoma can present as a shiny, skin-colored bump that's translucent, meaning you can see a bit through the surface. The bump can look pearly white or pink on white skin.It can also present as ulcerated nodule on nasolabial fold with in a burrowing in appearance known as rodent ulcer.
Option B-Most melanomas are brown and black, but they can also be pink, tan, or white. Option C-Squamous cell carcinoma has everted edges.
Option D-Kaposi Sarcoma presents as cancerous lesions (spots) on the skin that are purple, red or brown and can appear flat or raised.

questions.text: A Patient presented with borderline leprosy of the face.which nerve is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The most common cranial nerve affected in leprosy is facial nerve>trigeminal nerve. Hence,CN7 is a better answer than CN5.

questions.text: A 25 years old male presented to OPD with complaint of recurrent oral ulcers and congested eyes. On enquiry he has h/o prior hospital admission for venous thrombosis. What is the condition he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Behçet’s disease.

Behçet’s disease is a chronic, multisystem inflammatory disorder that often presents in young adults, especially males, and is characterized by a triad of recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis (eye inflammation). In this case, the patient has recurrent oral ulcers, eye redness (likely uveitis or conjunctivitis), and a history of venous thrombosis, which is a well-known vascular complication in Behçet’s due to its predilection for causing both arterial and venous inflammation (vasculitis). The presence of mucocutaneous, ocular, and vascular symptoms in a young adult strongly supports the diagnosis of Behçet’s disease. This condition is common along the “Silk Road” region (Middle East to East Asia), but it can be seen globally.

A. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus) – Incorrect.
While SLE can present with oral ulcers and vascular thrombosis (especially in antiphospholipid syndrome), it is more common in females, and ocular involvement typically presents as retinal vasculitis or lupus retinopathy rather than uveitis. Genital ulcers are not typical of SLE, making Behçet’s more likely in this presentation.
B. Reiter’s syndrome (Reactive arthritis) – Incorrect.
Reiter’s syndrome presents with the triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, often after a genitourinary or gastrointestinal infection. However, oral ulcers and venous thrombosis are not characteristic, and the absence of arthritis or a preceding infection argues against this diagnosis.
D. Wegener’s Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis) – Incorrect.

Wegener’s typically involves upper and lower respiratory tract symptoms (e.g., sinusitis, nasal ulcers, hemoptysis) and glomerulonephritis. Although it may cause oral or nasal ulcers, it does not typically present with venous thrombosis or conjunctival injection without respiratory or renal signs. Also, it's rare in young adults.

questions.text: Identify the condition associated with the murmur depicted in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mitral regurgitation.

The murmur depicted in the image (presumably a phonocardiogram) is characteristic of mitral regurgitation (MR). MR produces a high-pitched, blowing holosystolic murmur that begins with S1 (first heart sound) and continues through S2 (second heart sound) without a gap. It is best heard at the apex of the heart and typically radiates to the axilla. This murmur results from retrograde blood flow from the left ventricle to the left atrium during systole due to an incompetent mitral valve. MR can occur due to causes such as mitral valve prolapse, rheumatic heart disease, ischemic heart disease, or infective endocarditis.

B. Aortic regurgitation – Incorrect.
Aortic regurgitation produces an early diastolic decrescendo murmur, not a systolic one. It is best heard at the left sternal border with the patient leaning forward and holding their breath in expiration. The murmur occurs after S2, which doesn’t match the timing of the murmur seen in MR.
C. Aortic stenosis – Incorrect.
Aortic stenosis presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, best heard at the right upper sternal border and radiating to the carotids. While it's a systolic murmur like MR, it has a diamond- shaped (ejection) profile, not a flat, holosystolic one.
D. Mitral stenosis – Incorrect.
Mitral stenosis causes a low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur, often preceded by an opening snap. It’s best heard at the apex in the left lateral position. It occurs after S2, during diastole, and is not a systolic murmur like in MR.

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ankylosing Spondylitis
The most probable diagnosis is Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS), a chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints, leading to stiffness and pain. This patient presents with early morning backache and stiffness that improves with exercise, a hallmark of AS. The persistent red eyes are likely due to associated iritis or uveitis, which are common extra-articular manifestations of AS. The reduced lung expansion (<3 cm) can be explained by the progressive spinal involvement and thoracic cage stiffness, which limits lung expansion. On X-ray, characteristic findings of AS, such as sacroiliitis and the bamboo spine, may be visible, confirming the diagnosis.

Incorrect Answers:

B. Paget’s Disease
Paget's disease of bone typically causes bone deformities and fractures, but it does not commonly present with early morning backache or stiffness improving with exercise. The hallmark feature of Paget's disease is abnormal bone remodeling, often seen in the pelvis, spine, and skull. However, it is not typically associated with red eyes or significant lung involvement. X-ray findings in Paget’s disease show bone enlargement and thickening, not the typical features of AS.

C. Healed Tuberculosis
Healed tuberculosis can cause residual effects, such as fibrosis or lung restriction, but it would not typically present with early morning back stiffness that improves with exercise or red eyes. Moreover, healed TB would not lead to the characteristic sacroiliac joint involvement or bamboo spine seen in AS. The X-ray may show old pulmonary scars, but the patient's clinical symptoms and presentation do not align with healed TB.

D. Osteopetrosis
Osteopetrosis, or marble bone disease, is a genetic condition characterized by abnormal bone hardening due to defective osteoclast function. It leads to increased bone density, which may be evident on X-ray, but it typically presents with bone fractures, cranial nerve palsies, and hearing loss rather than back stiffness or red eyes. This condition does not involve the spine in a manner consistent with ankylosing spondylitis, nor does it cause lung restriction or extra-articular manifestations like uveitis.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

IV Mannitol

The most likely diagnosis here is dialysis disequilibrium syndrome, a rare but serious complication that can occur during or shortly after dialysis. It is characterized by neurological symptoms such as drowsiness, seizures, and hypotension. The condition arises due to an osmotic gradient between the blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) caused by the rapid reduction of urea and other solutes during dialysis. This leads to water shifting into the brain, causing cerebral edema and the associated neurological symptoms. IV Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that can help reduce cerebral edema by drawing water out of the brain and into the bloodstream, which helps alleviate the symptoms of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome.

Incorrect Answers:

A.    Bumetanide
Bumetanide is a loop diuretic used to treat conditions like edema and fluid retention. It acts on the kidneys to increase urine output. While it can help manage fluid balance, it is not effective for treating cerebral edema or the neurological complications of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome. The issue in this case is not fluid overload but rather the osmotic imbalance caused by dialysis, which makes bumetanide inappropriate.

B.    Ethacrynic Acid
Ethacrynic acid, like bumetanide, is a loop diuretic used for conditions involving fluid retention. It functions similarly to bumetanide, increasing urine output. However, it does not address the underlying issue of cerebral edema caused by the osmotic shifts that occur during dialysis. Therefore, it is not the correct treatment in this situation.

C.    Nesiritide
Nesiritide is a recombinant form of B-type natriuretic peptide used to treat acute decompensated heart failure by reducing fluid overload and vasodilation. While it can reduce symptoms of heart failure, it does not help with the cerebral edema associated with dialysis disequilibrium syndrome. It is primarily used for cardiac issues, not for managing neurological complications after dialysis.

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Diltiazem

The patient is presenting with symptoms that strongly suggest thyroid storm—a severe form of hyperthyroidism, which can manifest with symptoms like restlessness, palpitations, tremors, elevated blood pressure, tachycardia, and atrial fibrillation. Additionally, the swollen neck indicates a possible goiter, a classic sign of thyroid dysfunction. The immediate management of thyroid storm involves controlling the heart rate and managing the underlying hyperthyroidism. Diltiazem, a calcium channel blocker, is used in this situation to control the tachycardia and atrial fibrillation. It is preferred in patients with thyroid storm who have a history of bronchial asthma because, unlike beta- blockers, it does not cause bronchoconstriction and is safe for asthmatic patients.

Incorrect Answers:

B. Propranolol
Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used in the management of thyroid storm to control tachycardia and atrial fibrillation. However, it should be avoided in this patient because she has bronchial asthma, and beta-blockers can worsen bronchoconstriction, leading to an asthma attack. Although propranolol can be beneficial in controlling heart rate, it poses a risk in patients with respiratory conditions, making it less suitable for this case.

C. Esmolol
Esmolol is a short-acting beta-blocker that is typically used in cases where rapid heart rate control is needed. While it could theoretically help control the tachycardia in thyroid storm, it is not ideal for this patient because, like propranolol, it can cause bronchoconstriction in asthmatic patients. Therefore, its use is contraindicated in this case due to the risk of exacerbating asthma symptoms.
D. Propylthiouracil
Propylthiouracil (PTU) is an antithyroid medication that can be used to block the synthesis of thyroid hormones and treat hyperthyroidism. While it is an important part of the management of thyroid storm, PTU does not provide immediate control of tachycardia or atrial fibrillation, which are the acute concerns in this patient. Immediate management focuses on controlling the heart rate and symptoms, which is why a drug like diltiazem is preferred in this case.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found to be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg and is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. The viral load of the patient was 2 x 100000 and SGPT is found to be doubled. What is appropriate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tenofovir for > 40 weeks

The patient is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B, indicated by the presence of HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) and HBeAg (hepatitis B e antigen), which suggests active viral replication. The patient has an elevated viral load (2 x 10^5 copies/mL), which confirms active replication of the virus, along with a doubling of SGPT (serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase), indicating liver inflammation. Given these findings, Tenofovir, a nucleos(t)ide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), is an appropriate treatment for chronic hepatitis B due to its high potency and low resistance profile. Tenofovir is typically used for long-term management, often for >40 weeks (and potentially indefinitely, depending on response). It effectively reduces viral replication and liver inflammation, reducing the risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Incorrect Answers:

A. Lamivudine for 30+ weeks
Lamivudine is another NRTI used to treat chronic hepatitis B, but it is less ideal in this patient. Lamivudine has a higher rate of resistance over time, especially in patients with high viral loads, such as this one. While it can be used initially, it is generally not recommended for long-term therapy in patients with significant viral replication due to the risk of resistance. Therefore, Tenofovir is preferred over lamivudine for longer-term therapy.

C. Pegylated interferon for 52 weeks
Pegylated interferon is an immune-modulating agent that can be used to treat chronic hepatitis B. However, it is usually reserved for patients with HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B or those who do not have high viral loads. It is not the first-line therapy for patients with high viral loads and active hepatitis, as in this case, due to its adverse side effects, including flu-like symptoms, bone marrow suppression, and potential thyroid dysfunction. The treatment duration (52 weeks) can also be challenging for some patients. Therefore, Tenofovir is the more appropriate choice in this case.

D. Combined pegylated interferon with lamivudine
Combining pegylated interferon with lamivudine is not standard practice in the treatment of chronic hepatitis B. While the combination therapy might have some theoretical benefits, it is not preferred due to the increased risk of resistance with lamivudine and the significant side effects associated with interferon therapy. This combination does not offer any clear advantage over Tenofovir monotherapy, which is both safer and more effective in reducing viral load and liver inflammation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient came with complaints of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He has a complaint of sweaty palms. Clinical findings are depicted in the image given below. What is the diagnostic finding seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thyroid receptor antibody

The patient presents with symptoms like palpitations, sweating, restlessness, and sweaty palms, which are suggestive of hyperthyroidism or an overactive thyroid. The clinical findings, likely involving signs like exophthalmos (protruding eyes) or a goiter, suggest the possibility of Graves' disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. The key diagnostic finding in this condition is the presence of thyroid receptor antibodies (TRAb), which are autoantibodies that stimulate the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor, leading to increased thyroid hormone production. These antibodies are characteristic of Graves' disease, confirming the diagnosis.

Incorrect Answers:

A. Anti-thyroglobulin antibody
Anti-thyroglobulin antibodies are often associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, an autoimmune condition that causes hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism. These antibodies can be elevated in autoimmune thyroid diseases, but they are not specific to Graves' disease or hyperthyroidism. Therefore, anti-thyroglobulin antibodies would not be the diagnostic finding in this patient with symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

B. Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody
Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies are also primarily associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and some cases of autoimmune thyroid disease. They are markers of thyroid inflammation and can be found in patients with hypothyroidism. Like anti-thyroglobulin antibodies, they are not specific to Graves' disease or hyperthyroidism. Thus, this would not be the correct diagnostic finding for a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of hyperthyroidism.

D. Elevated ultrasensitive thyrotropin levels
In hyperthyroidism, thyrotropin (TSH) levels are typically low, not elevated. This is because the body decreases TSH production in response to high levels of circulating thyroid hormones (T3 and T4). An elevated ultrasensitive TSH level would be seen in hypothyroidism, where the feedback mechanism causes TSH levels to rise. Therefore, elevated TSH levels would not support a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism or Graves' disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Kaposi Sarcoma

The most likely diagnosis in this 50-year-old HIV-positive patient with a painful skin lesion is Kaposi sarcoma. Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular tumor associated with Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and occurs most commonly in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with AIDS. It presents as painful, purple or dark red plaques or nodules that can appear on the skin, oral mucosa, and internal organs. The lesions are often multiple and may be non-blanching due to their vascular nature. Kaposi sarcoma is a common AIDS-defining illness and is strongly linked to low CD4 counts. The appearance of the lesion in an HIV-positive patient is characteristic and highly suggestive of this diagnosis.

Incorrect Answers:

A.    Basal Cell Carcinoma
Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, but it typically presents as a pearly papule with rolled borders and central ulceration, usually in sun-exposed areas like the face. BCC grows slowly and is rarely painful. It is not associated with HIV or immunosuppression and does not appear as violaceous or vascular lesions, making it unlikely in this case.

C.    Malignant Melanoma
Malignant melanoma often presents as a pigmented lesion with features described by the ABCDE rule (Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variation, Diameter >6 mm, Evolving). While melanoma can occur in immunocompromised patients, it is generally not painful in early stages and is not associated with the typical vascular, purplish lesions seen in Kaposi sarcoma. The clinical context and lesion appearance are more consistent with Kaposi sarcoma.

D.    Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)
SCC can present as a scaly, crusted, or ulcerated lesion, often in sun-exposed areas, and can become painful. However, SCC usually lacks the violaceous or reddish-purple vascular appearance of Kaposi sarcoma and is more common in older individuals with a history of chronic sun exposure or immunosuppression (e.g., transplant recipients). Although HIV patients are at increased risk for SCC, the lesion described is more typical of Kaposi sarcoma.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD by his wife complaining about difficulty in expressing emotions and not taking part in daily activities. On examination, resting tremors and rigidity are noted. Given the possible diagnosis, which part of the brain is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Basal Ganglia

The patient presents with resting tremors, rigidity, and reduced emotional expression and motivation, all of which are classic features of Parkinson’s disease. Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects the basal ganglia, particularly the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to a deficiency in dopamine. The basal ganglia are deeply involved in the regulation of voluntary motor control, muscle tone, and movement initiation, as well as certain non-motor functions like motivation and emotional expression. The hallmark motor features (resting tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia) and non-motor features (affective flattening, apathy) seen in this patient directly result from basal ganglia dysfunction, confirming it as the affected region.
Incorrect Answers:

B.    Hippocampus
The hippocampus is primarily involved in learning and memory formation, particularly in short-term to long-term memory consolidation. Damage to the hippocampus is typically associated with memory loss or amnesia, not with motor symptoms like tremors and rigidity. Therefore, it does not explain the clinical picture seen in this patient.

C.    Cerebellum
The cerebellum coordinates balance, posture, and fine motor movements, especially during active movement. Cerebellar lesions typically result in ataxia, intention tremor, and dysmetria, not the resting tremor and rigidity seen in this patient. Hence, while the cerebellum is important for motor function, the nature of the motor symptoms points away from cerebellar involvement.

D.    Premotor Cortex
The premotor cortex helps plan and organize voluntary movements. Lesions here may cause difficulty initiating voluntary movement (apraxia), but they do not typically cause the tremor, rigidity, or emotional blunting observed in Parkinson's disease. Thus, while this area plays a role in motor planning, it is not the primary site affected in this scenario.

questions.text: A 45 year old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions that appear as umbilicated papules and nodules predominantly on the face, trunk, and upper extremities. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis

The clinical presentation of a 45-year-old HIV-positive male with persistent cough, weight loss, umbilicated papular skin lesions, and bilateral nodular infiltrates on chest X-ray, combined with a negative CBNAAT for tuberculosis and low CD4 count, strongly suggests disseminated histoplasmosis. Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus that commonly affects immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with AIDS and CD4 counts <150 cells/mm³. The disease often begins as a pulmonary infection and can progress to disseminated disease, especially in immunocompromised hosts. Skin lesions in disseminated histoplasmosis may mimic molluscum contagiosum (umbilicated papules), and the lung involvement with systemic symptoms like weight loss is consistent with fungal dissemination. This constellation of findings points toward disseminated histoplasmosis, which is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients in endemic areas.

Incorrect Answers:
B. HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis
Cryptococcosis, caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, typically presents in HIV patients with central nervous system symptoms, such as meningitis, and less commonly with pulmonary or cutaneous manifestations. Although disseminated cryptococcosis can involve the lungs and skin, umbilicated papular skin lesions are less classic, and cough and bilateral pulmonary nodules are more characteristic of histoplasmosis. Moreover, cryptococcal skin lesions are often less numerous and not primarily distributed on the face and trunk.

C. HIV with molluscum contagiosum
Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by a poxvirus, which presents with umbilicated papules and is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV. However, molluscum contagiosum is limited to the skin and does not cause systemic symptoms like cough, weight loss, or pulmonary infiltrates. The presence of systemic signs and pulmonary nodular infiltrates rules out molluscum contagiosum as the primary diagnosis.

D. HIV with tuberculosis
While tuberculosis (TB) is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients and can present with cough and weight loss, the diagnosis is unlikely here because the CBNAAT for TB was negative. Moreover, TB does not typically present with umbilicated skin lesions, which are much more characteristic of fungal infections like histoplasmosis. Also, bilateral nodular infiltrates are more typical of fungal dissemination than TB in this context.

questions.text: A male patient presented to the emergency room with seizures. He has a history of fever, headache, and confusion. An MRI brain was done, and it showed inflammation involving the bitemporal lobe. What is the most likely etiology for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Herpes simplex virus

The most likely etiology for a patient presenting with seizures, fever, headache, confusion, and MRI showing inflammation of the bitemporal lobes is Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) encephalitis, particularly caused by HSV-1. HSV encephalitis is the most common cause of sporadic fatal encephalitis in adults. It characteristically affects the temporal lobes, leading to necrosis, edema, and hemorrhagic inflammation, which explains the bitemporal involvement seen on MRI. Clinically, patients often present with altered mental status, seizures, and focal neurologic signs, and if left untreated, the condition can rapidly progress to coma or death. Early recognition and treatment with IV acyclovir are crucial to improve outcomes.

Incorrect Answers:

A. Cytomegalovirus
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) typically causes ventriculoencephalitis or polyradiculopathy in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with advanced HIV/AIDS. It does not usually cause
 
isolated bitemporal lobe inflammation, and seizures are less commonly the initial presenting symptom compared to HSV. Thus, CMV is unlikely in this scenario.
B. Toxoplasma gondii
Toxoplasma gondii is a parasitic infection that commonly affects HIV-positive patients with CD4 counts <100. It typically presents with ring-enhancing lesions on MRI, primarily in the basal ganglia or corticomedullary junction, rather than the temporal lobes. The presence of bitemporal inflammation makes HSV a more probable diagnosis.
D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis
CNS tuberculosis usually manifests as tuberculous meningitis, tuberculomas, or abscesses, often involving the basal cisterns or posterior fossa and not specifically the temporal lobes. The presentation is more subacute or chronic, with cranial nerve palsies, hydrocephalus, and meningeal signs, rather than acute seizures and bitemporal inflammation.

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

The most probable diagnosis is Subacute Combined Degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord, which is caused by vitamin B12 deficiency. This condition leads to demyelination of the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts, resulting in the characteristic combination of sensory loss (especially proprioception and vibration sense), upper motor neuron (UMN) signs in the lower limbs (e.g., spasticity, weakness), and absent deep tendon reflexes due to peripheral nerve involvement. The presence of angular stomatitis supports a nutritional deficiency, particularly of B vitamins. The chronic progression over 3 months also aligns with SCD. Patients may also have ataxia, a positive Romberg sign, and in advanced cases, neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Incorrect Answers:

A.    Extradural cord compression
Extradural compression (e.g., from tumor or abscess) typically causes localized back pain, progressive motor weakness, and sensory level deficits, often with a more acute or subacute onset. It doesn't explain the nutritional signs like angular stomatitis, and loss of vibration and proprioception with UMN signs in the absence of a discrete sensory level is more suggestive of SCD.

B.    Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
ALS affects both upper and lower motor neurons, causing progressive muscle weakness, wasting, and fasciculations. However, sensory pathways are typically spared, so loss of proprioception and vibration sense would not be explained. The presence of angular stomatitis also makes ALS less likely.

C.    Multiple sclerosis (MS)
MS may cause multifocal neurological deficits, including UMN signs and sensory loss, but it typically presents in younger patients (20–40 years old), often with relapsing-remitting episodes. It also rarely causes nutritional deficiency signs like angular stomatitis. Moreover, MS would not classically present with such symmetrical and chronic sensory-motor findings.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitations, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent ‘a’ wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tricuspid Stenosis

The most likely diagnosis is Tricuspid Stenosis (TS), which is characterized by chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, a mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border, and a prominent ‘a’ wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP). Tricuspid stenosis impedes the flow of blood from the right atrium to the right ventricle during diastole, causing right atrial enlargement, which in turn leads to a prominent 'a' wave on JVP due to increased resistance during atrial contraction. The diastolic murmur is due to turbulent flow across the narrowed tricuspid valve during diastole. This condition is more common in rheumatic heart disease and is often associated with other valvular lesions.

Incorrect Answers:

A.    Mitral Stenosis
Mitral stenosis also causes a mid-diastolic murmur, but it is typically heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position, not at the left sternal border. It causes pulmonary congestion and left atrial enlargement, which may produce a tapping apex beat or opening snap, but does not cause a prominent 'a' wave on JVP, as it affects the left heart.

C.    Mitral Regurgitation
Mitral regurgitation presents with a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex and radiating to the axilla, not a mid-diastolic murmur. It leads to volume overload of the left atrium and ventricle, but again, does not affect JVP or produce a prominent 'a' wave.
D.    Tricuspid Regurgitation
Tricuspid regurgitation produces a pansystolic murmur that increases with inspiration (Carvallo’s sign) and is best heard at the lower left sternal border. It may cause giant v waves in the JVP due to regurgitant flow during systole, not prominent 'a' waves. Hence, it does not fit the auscultatory or JVP findings in this case.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of hypertension on multiple anti-hypertensive medications came to OPD. His ECG finding is given below. Which of the below drugs is responsible for the ECG finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Spironolactone

The ECG in a hypertensive patient on multiple antihypertensives likely shows peaked T waves, widened QRS, or other signs consistent with hyperkalemia—a known side effect of spironolactone, a potassium-sparing diuretic. Spironolactone acts as an aldosterone antagonist, reducing sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal nephron. This leads to potassium retention, which can result in hyperkalemia, especially in patients with renal impairment or those on other medications that affect potassium balance. ECG changes in hyperkalemia include tall, peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, flattened P waves, and eventually widened QRS complex—which can be life-threatening. Therefore, spironolactone is the most likely drug responsible for these ECG findings.

Incorrect Answers:

A.    Prazosin
Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker used for hypertension. It primarily causes vasodilation and may lead to postural hypotension, but it does not typically affect serum potassium levels or produce ECG changes suggestive of hyperkalemia. Hence, it is unlikely to be responsible for the ECG findings.
B.    Metoprolol
Metoprolol is a beta-1 selective blocker that may cause bradycardia or AV nodal delay, but it is not associated with electrolyte imbalances like hyperkalemia. It may cause flattened T waves or prolonged PR interval in overdose, but not the characteristic changes of hyperkalemia.
C.    Hydrochlorothiazide
Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that leads to potassium loss (hypokalemia), not hyperkalemia. Hypokalemia typically produces ECG findings such as U waves, flattened T waves, and ST depression, which are opposite to the changes seen in hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 78 year old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activities. She gives a history of convulsions and visual hallucinations. She does not talk to anyone and keeps looking at the sky. Pathology examination shows the presence of Lewy bodies within the neurons. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Parkinson’s disease

The most likely diagnosis is Parkinson’s disease, particularly a Parkinson’s disease dementia (PDD) variant, given the patient's progressive functional decline, visual hallucinations, convulsions, and neuropathology showing Lewy bodies in neurons. Lewy bodies are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions composed primarily of alpha-synuclein, and are a hallmark of Parkinson's disease and related disorders. While the classic presentation of Parkinson’s includes motor symptoms like resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability, cognitive decline and neuropsychiatric symptoms such as hallucinations often develop in later stages. The behavioral symptoms like social withdrawal and fixed gaze behavior further support a neurodegenerative process involving subcortical and cortical structures.

Incorrect Answers:

B.    Prion disease
Prion diseases (e.g., Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) can present with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, and EEG abnormalities, but Lewy bodies are not found in prion disorders. Prion diseases are marked by spongiform changes, not alpha-synuclein aggregates. Additionally, visual hallucinations are less characteristic, and the course is typically more rapid than described here.
C.    Huntington’s chorea
Huntington’s disease is a genetic disorder that presents earlier (typically in the 30s–50s) with a triad of chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and cognitive decline. It is autosomal dominant and caused by CAG repeat expansions in the HTT gene. Lewy bodies are not seen in Huntington’s disease, and seizures and hallucinations are not early or prominent features.

D.    Alzheimer’s disease
Alzheimer’s is the most common cause of dementia, usually associated with gradual memory loss and executive dysfunction. While hallucinations can occur, they are not as prominent or early as in Parkinson-related dementias. Pathology in Alzheimer’s shows amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, not Lewy bodies. Convulsions are also not typical in early Alzheimer's.

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 week and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors so no treatment required

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na+ levels were found to be 155 mEq/L, urine osmolarity was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

DDAVP supplements for lifelong

The patient presents with polyuria, hypernatremia (Na? = 155 mEq/L), and low urine osmolality (200 mOsm/kg), in the context of a history of total hypophysectomy, strongly indicating central diabetes insipidus (CDI). CDI results from deficiency of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) due to damage or removal of the posterior pituitary or hypothalamus. The definitive treatment is lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation, a synthetic analog of ADH, which helps concentrate the urine and correct the water imbalance. Without ADH, patients are unable to retain free water, leading to high serum sodium levels and dilute urine, which can result in dehydration and neurologic symptoms if left untreated. Lifelong therapy is essential because the underlying cause (hypophysectomy) is permanent and irreversible.

Incorrect Answers:

A.    DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
This is incorrect because CDI due to total hypophysectomy is a permanent condition, and the body cannot regenerate ADH production. Temporary treatment would not address the chronic nature of the hormone deficiency.
C.    Upsetting of receptors so no treatment required
This option confuses nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (where ADH receptors are dysfunctional) with central DI. In central DI, the problem lies in ADH production, not receptor sensitivity. Thus, treatment is required, and receptor function is intact.
D.    Thiazides for 2 weeks
Thiazides may be used as a symptomatic treatment in nephrogenic DI, where they reduce polyuria through paradoxical mechanisms. However, in central DI, thiazides do not address the hormonal deficiency and are not definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 65 year old chronic smoker came to the medicine OPD with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest x-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pancoast tumor The most likely diagnosis is Pancoast tumor, a type of lung cancer that typically occurs at the apex of the lung, often involving the superior pulmonary sulcus. This type of tumor can cause upper chest discomfort and radiating pain due to its proximity to the brachial plexus and sympathetic nerve chain. The symptoms described, including drooping of the eyelid (ptosis), pain radiating to the upper arm, and tingling in the 4th and 5th digits of the left hand, are classic signs of Horner’s syndrome, which occurs when the sympathetic nerves are involved. Horner’s syndrome can result from the tumor compressing the sympathetic pathway, leading to ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis. Chest x-ray findings of a mass at the apex of the lung would support this diagnosis. Incorrect Answers: B. Upper lobe pneumonia While upper lobe pneumonia can cause chest discomfort and pain, it is less likely to cause Horner’s syndrome or the neurological symptoms described (e.g., tingling in the 4th and 5th digits). Pneumonia would typically present with symptoms such as fever, cough, and dyspnea, and would show consolidation or infiltrates in the upper lobe on chest x-ray, not a mass like a Pancoast tumor. C. Superior vena cava obstruction Superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction presents with symptoms such as facial and upper extremity edema, jugular venous distension, and cyanosis, due to the impaired venous return to the heart. While this could cause chest discomfort, it would not explain the ptosis or the tingling in the hand. The x-ray would show features of SVC obstruction, such as a mediastinal mass or enlarged veins. The absence of these signs and the specific neurological findings make SVC obstruction less likely in this case. D. Aspergilloma Aspergilloma, or a fungal ball, typically forms in pre-existing lung cavities, often in individuals with previous lung disease, such as tuberculosis or emphysema. It usually causes hemoptysis, cough, and dyspnea rather than the neurological symptoms seen in this patient. The x- ray findings would typically show a fungal ball within a lung cavity, which is not consistent with the findings of a Pancoast tumor.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. There is no history of trauma. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leukocytes. Lab investigations show normal serum uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pseudogout
The most likely diagnosis is pseudogout. This condition, also known as calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), is characterized by acute pain and swelling in a joint, most commonly the knee or wrist, but it can affect the great toe as well. The key differentiating factor in this case is the absence of elevated serum uric acid levels, which rules out gout. Instead, calcium pyrophosphate crystals are deposited in the joint, leading to an inflammatory response. On synovial fluid analysis, CPPD is diagnosed when rhomboid-shaped crystals with positive birefringence are found under polarized light microscopy. Chronic alcohol use is a risk factor for pseudogout, as it is associated with calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition.

Incorrect Answers:

B.    Acute gout
Acute gout is characterized by sudden onset of pain, swelling, and redness, typically involving the big toe (podagra), but serum uric acid levels are often elevated, especially during an acute flare. This patient's normal serum uric acid level makes acute gout less likely. Additionally, monosodium urate crystals in the synovial fluid would be seen in gout, but there is no mention of the characteristic needle-shaped crystals with negative birefringence that are typically seen in gout.

C.    Reactive arthritis
Reactive arthritis often follows an infection, typically urinary or gastrointestinal. It presents with the classic triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis (the "cant see, can't pee, can't climb a tree" syndrome). This patient does not report a history of infection or the typical symptoms of urethritis or conjunctivitis, so reactive arthritis is not a likely diagnosis.
D.    Septic arthritis
Septic arthritis can present with acute joint pain and swelling and is typically caused by bacterial infection. However, it usually presents with severe pain, fever, and systemic signs of infection, and synovial fluid analysis would show a high white blood cell count, often greater than 50,000/µL with predominantly neutrophils. The absence of these signs, particularly the absence of fever and the presence of normal white blood cell count, makes septic arthritis unlikely in this case.

questions.text: A patient presented with acute onset of left sided weakness and loss of proprioception and vibration sense over left side of the body with facial sparing. On protrusion of tongue, it deviates to the right side. Which artery is involved:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anterior Spinal Artery

Explanation for Correct Answer:

The clinical features described—acute onset left-sided weakness, loss of proprioception and vibration sense on the left side of the body, and facial sparing—are highly indicative of a medial medullary syndrome (also known as Dejerine syndrome), which is caused by an infarction in the region supplied by the anterior spinal artery. The anterior spinal artery supplies the medial portion of the medulla, where the pyramidal tract (for motor function) and medial lemniscus (for proprioception and vibration sense) are located. The deviation of the tongue to the right on protrusion indicates right-sided hypoglossal nerve involvement, as the hypoglossal nerve nuclei are also located in the medulla. Thus, the anterior spinal artery is the artery most commonly involved in this type of presentation, causing both motor and sensory deficits with facial sparing.

Incorrect Options:

A.    Middle Cerebral Artery – Incorrect:

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies most of the lateral convexity of the cerebral hemisphere, including areas responsible for motor and sensory functions of the face, arm, and hand. However, the MCA does not supply the medulla or the structures described in this case (proprioception, vibration sense, and hypoglossal nerve function). MCA involvement would typically result in contralateral hemiparesis, sensory loss, and facial involvement, unlike the facial sparing seen in this case. Therefore, the MCA is not the correct answer.

B.    Anterior Cerebral Artery – Incorrect:

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the medial aspect of the frontal lobes and the paracentral lobule, which is involved in motor and sensory functions of the contralateral leg and foot. ACA occlusion can cause contralateral leg weakness or sensory loss, but it does not affect the medulla or structures such as the hypoglossal nerve or medial lemniscus. Additionally, there would likely be involvement of the leg, not sparing of the face, which further rules out the ACA as the cause of this patient’s symptoms.

C.    Posterior Cerebral Artery – Incorrect:

The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the occipital lobe and the inferior temporal lobe, as well as portions of the thalamus and midbrain. While PCA occlusion can result in visual deficits (e.g., homonymous hemianopia) or thalamic sensory disturbances, it does not supply the medulla where the structures involved in the patient's symptoms are located. Therefore, PCA involvement is not associated with the symptoms of weakness, proprioceptive loss, and hypoglossal nerve deviation seen here.

questions.text: A Patient with History of RTA presented to the OPD after 3 days. CT showed the presence of an SDH. On fundoscopy B/L papilledema was seen. What is the most probable course of this:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation for Incorrect Answers:

B. Meningitis – Incorrect:
Meningitis can cause raised ICP and papilledema, but it typically presents with fever, neck stiffness, photophobia, and altered mental status, which are not mentioned here. Additionally, there is a clear traumatic etiology and imaging confirmation of SDH, making raised ICP due to mass effect more likely.
C. Optic Neuritis – Incorrect:
Optic neuritis presents with unilateral vision loss, pain on eye movement, and sometimes changes in color vision. It does not cause bilateral papilledema or result from trauma or SDH. Moreover, optic disc swelling in optic neuritis is usually unilateral and not due to raised ICP.
D. Glaucoma – Incorrect:
Glaucoma is an eye condition involving increased intraocular pressure, not intracranial pressure. It typically presents with visual field defects and optic disc cupping, not papilledema. It is unrelated to trauma or SDH.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the deep inguinal ring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Option A-Internal oblique froms conjoint tendon.

Option B-External oblique has an opening called deep inguinal ring. Option C-Parietal peritoneum forms processus vaginalis.
Option D-The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.

questions.text: A student had his jaw locked while yawning. Which of the following muscles is attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lateral pterygoid:-

Origin- upper head of the Lateral pterygoid originates from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate.
Insertion- into the pterygoid fovea, the capsule of the temporomandibular joint and the articular disc.
The action of the Lateral pterygoid is depression, protrusion and side to side movement of the jaw.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the following histological image-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The structure shown in the following histological image is Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries lined by fenestrated endothelium. It is supported by the mesangium.
Other options-

questions.text: Injury at which site causes failure of dorsiflexion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Option A-A is lateral epicondyle of femur. Option B-B is head of fibula.
Option C-The site marked as ‘C’ in the given X-ray is the neck of fibula. Injury at this site causes failure of dorsiflexion (foot drop), loss of toe extension and eversion of the foot due to injury to the common fibular nerve. Sensory innervation of the dorsum of the foot including the first web space is also lost. The CPN (L4, L5, S1, S2) curves laterally round the neck of fibula and gets divided into the superficial and deep fibular nerves.
Option D-D is shaft of tibia.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following arches causes the defect shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Option A-4th right aortic arch gives rise to the proximal part of the right Subclavian artery. Option B-4th left aortic arch gives rise to arch of aorta.
Option C-6th right aortic arch forms the proximal part of the right pulmonary artery.

Option D-The image shows a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: Which of the following structures develops from the structure marked as A?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Option A-Medial Umbilical ligament forms from umbilical arteries.

Option B-The structure marked is the Allantois. Its distal portion forms the urachus, which in turn gives rise to the median umbilical ligament.
Option C-Meckels diverticulum is derived from vitellointestinal duct. Option D-Ligamentum teres is remnant of left umbilical vein.

choices.text: Left colic and middle colic veins
Esophageal veins and left gastric veins

questions.text: A patient comes with abdominal pain, jaundice, and portal hypertension. Anastomosis between which of the following veins is seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Option A-Left colic and middle colic veins are part of portal circulation.

Option B-In the given scenario of portal hypertension [abdominal pain, jaundice], anastomosis between esophageal veins and left gastric veins can be seen.
Option C-Superior rectal and phrenic veins do not anastomose with each other.
Option D-Sigmoid and superior rectal veins are part of portal circulation.

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling under the left ear lobule and complains of pain. Which of the following structures is the likely cause of pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Option A-Facial nerve is associated with Hitzelberger sign which is the numbness of the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal. It is seen in acoustic neuroma and is not associated with swelling over the parotid region.
Option B-The greater auricular nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin overlying the parotid gland and ear lobule.
Option C-The auriculotemporal nerve can cause referred pain due to caries tooth or ulcerative lesions of the oral cavity. However it is not the primary cause of pain in parotid region due to swelling.
Option D-Investing layer of deep cervical fascia itself does not transmit pain sensation.

choices.text: Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL.

questions.text: A 65 year old diabetic woman presents with painless loss of vision. The ocular findings are shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis and management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Immature senile cataract is a common condition in elderly individuals, especially those with diabetes. The patient presents with painless vision loss, which is characteristic of cataracts, particularly when the lens opacity becomes significant. The management for immature senile cataract includes phacoemulsification with intraocular lens (IOL) implantation, which is the standard surgical procedure for cataract removal Other Options: A) Zonular cataract and lensectomy: Zonular cataracts are different from senile cataracts and typically involve the zonules of the lens. Lensectomy is not the first-line treatment, and zonular cataracts may not match this presentation B) Rosette cataract and sugar control: Rosette cataracts are characterized by a particular pattern of opacity that is not typical for diabetic patients with senile cataracts. Sugar control is important for overall health but would not be sufficient as a primary treatment for cataracts C) Sunflower cataract and lesion extraction: Sunflower cataracts are a specific type of cataract associated with Wilson's disease, not typical for diabetic patients. The treatment for these is different and focuses on addressing the underlying condition

questions.text: Which of the following refractive errors is associated with the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sturm's Conoid refers to the visual pattern created when light rays from a point source focus at different points along two perpendicular meridians due to astigmatism. This occurs because the cornea or lens has an uneven curvature, causing the light entering the eye to focus on multiple points instead of a single point on the retina Astigmatism is the refractive error associated with Sturm's Conoid, where the eye's inability to focus light evenly causes distorted or blurred vision, especially at certain angles Other Options: A) Presbyopia ? Presbyopia is a condition related to age-related changes in the lens, resulting in difficulty focusing on near objects. It does not involve the creation of a conoid pattern and is unrelated to astigmatism C) Hypermetropia (Hyperopia) ? Hypermetropia or farsightedness is when distant objects are focused behind the retina due to the eye being too short or the cornea being too flat. It does not cause the Sturm's Conoid D) Myopia ? Myopia or nearsightedness is when close objects are focused in front of the retina. It is also not associated with the creation of Sturm's Conoid.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presents with a small nodule on the sclera as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dermoid is a benign growth composed of skin-like tissue, including hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and sweat glands. These cysts are commonly located in the limbal area (the junction between the cornea and sclera) and can appear as yellowish, smooth, firm nodules on the sclera Other Options: A) Pterygium is a benign growth of conjunctival tissue that extends over the cornea, typically due to chronic irritation from UV exposure. It is usually triangular in shape, not a small nodule B) Pinguecula is a yellowish, raised lesion on the conjunctiva (usually near the cornea), often caused by UV exposure or aging. It is not typically a nodule on the sclera C) Dermolipoma is a rare, benign congenital lesion composed of adipose tissue, but it is less likely to present as a small nodule on the sclera compared to a dermoid cyst

questions.text: The eye examination of a 20 year old male shows a golden ring on the iris. What is the next investigation to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The golden-brown ring on the iris described in the question is a Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring, which is a hallmark of Wilson’s disease (hepatolenticular degeneration). Wilson’s disease is a disorder of copper metabolism due to a mutation in the ATP7B gene, leading to copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and cornea. The first-line investigation is serum ceruloplasmin, which is typically low in Wilson’s disease Other options: A) Alpha-1 antitrypsin: Used for alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which presents with early-onset COPD and liver disease, not KF rings B) Alpha-fetoprotein: Marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and germ cell tumors, not Wilson’s disease C) Serum iron: Relevant for hemochromatosis, which causes bronze skin pigmentation, diabetes, and liver dysfunction, but not KF rings

choices.text: Fluorescein dye- visualised under green filter
Fluorescein dye- visualised under cobalt light filter

questions.text: What is the dye and filter used to diagnose corneal ulcers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Viral corneal ulcers, such as herpetic keratitis, are best visualized using fluorescein dye and a cobalt blue filter. Fluorescein dye stains areas of epithelial damage, allowing dendritic or geographic ulcers (caused by HSV) to be identified. Cobalt blue light enhances the fluorescence of the dye, making the ulcer appear bright green Other Options: A) Lissamine dye - Green filter: Lissamine green stains devitalized conjunctival and corneal epithelial cells but is not the primary choice for corneal ulcers B) Lissamine dye - Cobalt blue filter: Lissamine does not fluoresce under cobalt blue light C) Fluorescein dye - Green filter: Green filters enhance contrast but do not cause fluorescence like cobalt blue light does

questions.text: An infant is brought with complaints of excessive watering of the eyes and photophobia. The image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Congenital glaucoma is caused by impaired drainage of aqueous humor, leading to increased intraocular pressure (IOP) Classic Triad of Symptoms: • Epiphora • Photophobia
•    Blepharospasm Other Features in Advanced Cases: • Buphthalmos (Enlarged cornea due to increased IOP) • Corneal haziness • Optic nerve damage (if untreated, leading to vision loss) Other options: B) Congenital Cataract: Presents as painless leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) but does not cause excessive watering or photophobia C) Mucopolysaccharidosis: Can cause corneal clouding but is associated with skeletal deformities and developmental delay D) Ophthalmia Neonatorum: Neonatal conjunctivitis caused by bacterial infections (e.g., gonorrhea or chlamydia) but does not cause photophobia or buphthalmos

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient complains of decreased distant vision but now he does not use spectacles for near vision. What is this type of refractive error called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Index Myopia occurs due to changes in the refractive index of the lens, commonly seen in age-related nuclear cataracts. As the lens becomes denser and more opaque, its ability to refract light increases, leading to improved near vision (myopia) but worsened distance vision Other options: B) Axial Myopia: Caused by an increase in the length of the eyeball, not lens changes. It is congenital or develops in childhood C) Curvatural Myopia: Due to an increase in corneal curvature, not due to lens sclerosis D) Positional Myopia: Caused by a change in lens position, which is rare and does not explain this case

questions.text: A 30 year old male presents with nonaxial proptosis of the left eye. The patient gives a history of a road traffic accident 15 years back. The CT image is given below. What Is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Frontal mucocele Mucoceles are slow growing, mucous-filled benign masses that can develop years after head injury. Post-traumatic mucocele formation occurs due to chronic obstruction of the sinus ostium. The frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele formation.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Upper airway examination The image shows a tracheostomy tube. It is not used for upper airway examination. Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. Functions- 1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction 2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space 3. Uses a cuff to protect the airway from secretions 4. Allows suction of secretions in impaired cough reflex 5. Allows administration of anesthesia

questions.text: A 10 year old child presents with throat pain, fever and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve The tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis. The referred pain may be secondary to lesions or inflammatory processes of the nasopharynx, palatine tonsil, soft palate or posterior one third of the tongue.

questions.text: A 55 year old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Total laryngectomy The given image shows a post-operative stumpcreated for breathing in patients undergoing total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma. In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx is removed. The pharyngeal wall is repaired and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration.

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

30-45 dB A prediction of the air bone gap can be made using tuning forks of 256, 512 and 1024 Hz: A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz indicates airbone gap of 20-30 dB. A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz indicates airbone gap of 30-45 dB. A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz, 512 Hz, and 1024 Hz indicates airbone gap of 45-60 dB.

questions.text: A middle aged women presents with episodes of sudden onset breathlessness, palpitations, tremors, sweating, fear of having an impending cardiac arrest/heart attack since 6 months...increased heart rate,....5 to 6 episodes per month..., no triggers for such episode. each episode lasts for 30 minutes. All investigations were normal.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient's symptoms of sudden onset breathlessness, palpitations, tremors, sweating, and a fear of impending cardiac arrest or heart attack, occurring without any identifiable triggers and lasting for about 30 minutes, are consistent with panic attacks, a hallmark of panic disorder Other options: A) GAD (Generalized Anxiety Disorder): In GAD, anxiety is more chronic and generalized, with excessive worry about multiple issues (work, health, social situations), rather than discrete panic attacks C) Seizure disorder: Seizures typically involve a loss of consciousness, convulsions, or unusual movements, which were not described in this case D) Depression: While depression can have physical symptoms (fatigue, sleep disturbances, etc.), it is not typically characterized by acute episodes of panic or physical symptoms like breathlessness, palpitations, and sweating

questions.text: Patient of schizophrenia was first started on a haloperidol and thioridazine, but he wasn’t responding to that medicine, so was switched to another drug, but after switching he developed hyperglycaemia, dyslipidaemia and excessive salivation. What could be the offending drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The combination of hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia, and excessive salivation points toward clozapine as the offending drug Other options: B) Aripiprazole: This drug has a relatively favourable side effect profile compared to clozapine. It is less likely to cause hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia, or excessive salivation C) Ziprasidone: This atypical antipsychotic is also associated with a lower risk of metabolic side effects, including hyperglycemia and dyslipidemia
D) Risperidone: While risperidone can cause some metabolic effects, it is less commonly associated with excessive salivation or as severe metabolic disturbances as clozapine

questions.text: Clinical history is suggestive of premature ejaculation in male, with history of relationship conflicts with wife. Non pharmacological treatment for the couple used in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Squeeze therapy is a behavioral technique specifically designed to help men with premature ejaculation. It involves the partner squeezing the penis just below the glans at the moment the man feels he is about to ejaculate, delaying ejaculation and helping the individual gain control. Other options: B. Sensate focus technique is a form of sex therapy aimed at reducing performance anxiety and improving intimacy but is not specific for premature ejaculation C. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is useful for addressing psychological factors like anxiety or stress but is not the first-line intervention for premature ejaculation D. Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is used primarily in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and is not relevant for premature ejaculation management.

questions.text: History of chronic alcohol abuse now presented with acute onset confusion, 6th nerve palsy, gaze palsy, ataxia. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Wernicke encephalopathy is an acute neuropsychiatric syndrome caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in chronic alcoholics. It is characterized by the classic triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia (e.g., gaze palsy, sixth nerve palsy), and ataxia Other options: B. Korsakoff psychosis is a chronic condition that often follows untreated Wernicke encephalopathy and is associated with severe memory deficits and confabulation but does not present with acute ophthalmoplegia or ataxia C. Delirium tremens is a withdrawal syndrome seen in alcoholics that involves severe agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic hyperactivity, but it does not include ophthalmoplegia or ataxia D. De Clérambault syndrome is a delusional disorder where the individual believes another person is in love with them

questions.text: Identify the marked region in the given spirometry.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Functional residual capacity

The marked area shows the total amount of air present in the lung after normal expiration. This is called Functional residual capacity.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency after he suddenly became unconscious while working in the field. On examination, his temperature was 105 degrees Fahrenheit and his skin turgor was reduced. Which of the following will not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This patient likely has heat stroke, which is a medical emergency that occurs when the body's temperature regulation mechanisms fail due to prolonged exposure to high temperatures, leading to a core body temperature of 104°F or higher. It is associated with symptoms like confusion, unconsciousness, and organ dysfunction. In heat stroke, the body’s mechanisms for cooling itself are overwhelmed, and sweating is usually absent due to the failure of the hypothalamus to regulate the temperature effectively. Sweating, which is a natural cooling mechanism, tends to stop when a person is in heat stroke, despite the high temperature Other options: A) Tachypnoea: The body tries to compensate for the elevated temperature by increasing the respiratory rate in an attempt to cool down B) Hypotension: Heat stroke can lead to dehydration and a decrease in circulating blood volume, causing hypotension D) Red hot skin: As the body tries to dissipate heat, the skin often becomes flushed, red, and hot due to vasodilation, which can also be seen in heat stroke

choices.text: A- Glucose B- PAH C- Biacarbonate D- Inulin
A- Inulin B- Bicarbonate C- Glucose D- PAH
A- Glucose B- Inulin C- Bicarbonate D- PAH
A- Glucose B- Bicarbonate C- Inulin D- PAH

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A-Glucose, B-Bicarbonate, C-Inulin, D- PAH
PAH is filtered by the glomeruli and secreted by the tubular cells. Its concentration increases on moving through the length of nephron due to secretion into the tubules.
Inulin is freely filtered by the glomeruli and does not undergo any reabsorption or secretion hence its concentration remains constant.
The majority of bicarbonate reabsorption occurs in the proximal tubule and small amount of it reaches the distal tubules.
Glucose is reabsorbed along with sodium in the early portion of the proximal tubule.

choices.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is refractory period.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Point B to D is refractory period Point A represents the resting state where both channels are closed. Point B represents the threshold potential, when the initiation of action potential occurs. Rapid depolarization occurs to reach a point C. At point C, Na+ channels close and K+ channels open causing repolarization. Repolarisation continues till point D. At point E, Na+ channels are reset. K+ channels remain open causing after-hyperpolarisation. Excitability is reduced at point E. Point B-D is a part of refractory period. During this period, the application of even stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane given below-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Facilitated diffusion is a type of passive transport that occurs when molecules move across the cell membrane through specific transmembrane proteins (e.g., carrier proteins or channels). This process does not require energy (ATP) and occurs along the concentration gradient Other options: Simple diffusion (B): Does not involve transport proteins; molecules (e.g., gases or small lipophilic molecules) pass directly through the lipid bilayer Primary active transport (C): Requires ATP to move molecules against their concentration gradient (e.g., Na?/K? pump) Secondary active transport (D): Uses the energy of an existing gradient (created by primary active transport) to drive the movement of other substances

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased.
Both surface tension and compliance increased.
Surface tension decreased and compliance increased
Surface tension increased and compliance decreased

questions.text: What is true about the surface tension and compliance in a preterm baby delivered at 28 weeks who developed Respiratory distress syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In preterm infants with RDS • Surface tension is increased due to surfactant deficiency • Compliance is decreased due to alveolar collapse and stiff lungs

choices.text: First becomes more positive then negative

questions.text: In a patient with severe muscle injury and serum K+ level 5.5 mEq/L, what will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Becomes more positive In the given scenario, the patient has hyperkalemia. At a normal potassium concentration of 3.5-5 mEq/L, the equilibrium potential for potassium is -90 mV. This is close to the resting membrane potential of neurons which is about
-70mV. In hyperkalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is increased. Thus, the RMP moves closer to the threshold to elicit an action potential, leading to a more excitable nerve. This means the RMP becomes more positive.

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers

questions.text: A patient met with an RTA and developed a cervical spine injury. The lateral aspect of the dorsal column is injured. Which of the following findings are seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Injury to the lateral aspect of a dorsal column would affect the fasciculus cuneatus. This lesion would result in the absence of ipsilateral proprioception of the arm Other Options: B) Absence of contralateral arm proprioception: Proprioception is lost ipsilaterally because the dorsal column fibers cross over only in the medulla, not at the spinal level C) Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception: The lower limb proprioception is carried by the fasciculus gracilis (the medial aspect of the dorsal column), not the lateral aspect D) Absence of fine motor movement of fingers: This is a motor function controlled by the corticospinal tract, not the dorsal column

choices.text: Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channels
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the point marked on the myocardial action potential curve.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels The myocardial action potential curve marked above represents the plateau phase, which is due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from tongue to prostate is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Letulle method involves the en masse removal of all thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs as a single block. It allows for detailed examination of organ relationships and is commonly used in forensic autopsies Other options: Virchow method: Organs are removed one by one for individual examination Rokitansky method: In situ dissection of organs, removing them only after dissection Ghon method: Removal of organs in functional groups (thoracic, abdominal, and cervical)

questions.text: A HIV positive patient died, and his body was brought for post mortem. The method of autopsy to be done is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The Rokitansky autopsy method is commonly used for infectious disease cases, including HIV/AIDS, as it minimizes the risk of infection exposure to the pathologist Other options: A) Ghon Method: A limited autopsy method focusing on the lungs and is not used for full-body infectious disease cases B) Letulle Method (En Masse Removal): Entire organ systems are removed together and dissected externally, which increases the risk of exposure to infectious material C) Virchow Method (One-by-One Organ Removal): Each organ is removed separately, leading to higher aerosolization risks during dissection

questions.text: A male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals with picric acid. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Barberio test: A test for the presence of spermatozoa, where picric acid reacts with spermine in semen to form yellow, needle-shaped, rhombic crystals. This is useful in forensic cases of sexual assault Other options: Florence test: Detects choline in semen, forming brown, needle-shaped crystals with iodine and potassium iodide Teichmann test: A confirmatory test for blood, forming brown rhombic crystals of hematin with glacial acetic acid and salt Acid phosphatase test: Used for detecting semen, but it does not produce crystalline formations

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The hallmark of strychnine poisoning is recurrent episodes of generalized muscle spasms with opisthotonus (arching of the back) while the patient remains conscious in between episodes Other options: B) Ricinus: Causes gastrointestinal symptoms (severe vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain) and multi-organ failure, but no seizures C) Nerium odorum (Oleander Poisoning): Contains cardiac glycosides, leading to bradycardia, arrhythmias, and hyperkalemia, not opisthotonic seizures D) Datura (Anticholinergic Toxicity): Causes dilated pupils, hallucinations, dry mouth, hyperthermia, but does not cause recurrent seizures with opisthotonus

choices.text: Causing miscarriage with the consent of the mother
Causing miscarriage without the consent of mother
Death of the mother by act done with the intent to cause miscarriage
Causing death of the unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide

questions.text: Section 314 IPC deals with-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Section 314 IPC pertains to cases where a person performs an act with the intention of causing a miscarriage, and the mother dies as a result of that act, whether or not she consented. The section applies even if the act was not intended to cause the mother’s death but resulted in it Other options: Section 312 IPC: Causing miscarriage with consent Section 313 IPC: Causing miscarriage without consent Section 315 IPC: Preventing a child from being born alive or causing its death after birth

questions.text: The temperature of a body of a deceased person is found to be 39 degrees Celsius. Which of the following is the most probable reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
