In forensic medicine, a postmortem body temperature higher than normal (above 37°C) is most commonly due to septicemia or hyperpyrexial conditions before death Other Options: A) Cyanide poisoning: Typically causes rapid death and may lead to early postmortem cooling rather than hyperthermia C) Corrosive poisoning: Causes severe tissue damage (GI burns, perforation) but does not significantly elevate body temperature postmortem D) Intra-abdominal hemorrhage: Can lead to hypovolemic shock and death, but it does not cause postmortem hyperthermia

questions.text: A farmer felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Viper bite (especially Russell’s viper or saw-scaled viper) is known to cause local pain, swelling, and blistering around the bite site. Hemorrhagic manifestations due to venom-induced disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Persistent bleeding from the wound due to coagulopathy and platelet dysfunction. Systemic symptoms like drowsiness, hypotension, and shock Other options: Cobra bite (B) typically causes neurotoxic effects such as ptosis, respiratory paralysis, but does not lead to extensive bleeding or blistering Wasp sting (C) and Scorpion sting (D) cause pain, local swelling, and allergic reactions but are not associated with extensive bleeding or blister formation

questions.text: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vitamin C The likely clinical diagnosis is Neurolathyrism. Administration of Vitamin C at doses of 500-1000mg is beneficial for this. Lathyrism is paralyzing disease due to consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus. Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing this disease. It is water soluble and can be removed by the following methods: - Soaking pulses in hot water - Overnight soaking in lime water, followed by boiling -Parboiling- for large scale detoxification

choices.text: Wait till TB culture results to start ATT

questions.text: A 35 year old homeless man presented with a 1 month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest xray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ask for CBNAAT The given case points towards pulmonary tuberculosis. According to the NTEP guidelines, the next best line of management is CBNAAT. The initial diagnosis of pulmonary TB is done with sputum smear examination and chest radiography.

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between alanine dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. What type of study is being performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Retrospective cohort study A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before the investigations and study is undertaken.

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population is tracked from childhood to adulthood. It Is observed that those with lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood and vice versa. This can be best described as-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tracking of blood pressure The above phenomenon is best described as the “tracking” of blood pressure. In this phenomenon, the blood pressure of individuals is followed up from early childhood into adulthood. The BP in individuals with low BP tend to remain low, and in those with hgh BP tend to remain high.

questions.text: A 30 week primigravida c/o reduced vision at night. She has been avoiding papay, mango, and other fruits throughout her pregnancy as she thinks they are abortifacients. It is the primary duty of which of the following workers to provide counseling and information to the patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ASHA Amongst the given options, it is the duty of the ASHA to provide counseling and information to this pregnant patient. An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with education at least upto 8th grade, and in age group of 25-45 years. One ASHA per 1000 population is recommended.

questions.text: A 22 year old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gray The patient with vaginal discharge and erosions on the cervix has cervicitis from a sexually transmitted infection. She should be given a gray kit which contains cefixime and azithromycin.

choices.text: Years of life lost to morbidity
Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could have attributed to-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Years lost due to premature death It is mortality indicator that shows the number of years that a dying person could have expected to survive (usually taken 75 years). Mortality indicators are used as the starting point in the evaluation of health status. They are used as indirect indicators of health.

questions.text: In a 10 year old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

TT/Td vaccine A 10 year old school child will be administered TT/Td vaccine, as part of the school immunization program, as per the National Immunisation Schedule. Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria antigens, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. Scheduled to be administered at 10 and 16 years of age.

choices.text: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about cancer treatment according to the Colombo plan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Setting up cobalt therapy units Aid to set up cobalt therapy units for cancer treatment at medical institutions in India was part of the Colombo plan.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

BOAA Lathyrism is paralyzing disease due to consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus. Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing this disease. It is water soluble and can be removed by the following methods: -Soaking pulses in hot water - Overnight soaking in lime water, followed by boiling -Parboiling- for large scale detoxification

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.text: A young male came to the hospital with a clean-cut wound without any bleeding. The patient received a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. What is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Single-dose tetanus toxoid The patient with a clean cut wound without any bleeding, who has received a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago, should be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid vaccine and appropriate wound care.

choices.text: Collect water from already leaking taps
Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 min
Water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage
Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing Collecting water from leaking taps is not recommended as it increases the risk of contamination. It is recommended to let water flow for atleast 2 minutes to flush out stagnant water in the pipe. Keeping the sample close to the tap is not the main concern during water sample collection.

questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Recommended dietary allowance RDAs are essential for planning and assessing diets for healthy individuals and serve as a basis for food labeling, nutrition policy, and dietary guidelines.

choices.text: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure
Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.text: A boys hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Isolate for 6 days Isolation for 6 days is the appropriate measure to prevent further spread of the infection. Acyclovir and VZIG are not necessary for healthy individuals. High risk individuals who may benefit from VZIG include immunocompromised individuals, pregnant women, and newborns whose mothers developed chickenpox within 5 days before delivery or within 48 hrs after delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Infant mortality rate The Infant mortality rate (IMR) is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community. IMR= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total no of live births x 1000 It is one of the universally accepted healthcare indicators for the whole population and the socioeconomic conditions under which they live.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The given maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head tilt chin lift.

It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway. The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Option A,B,C-Penicillin,Erythromycin and Azithromycin are not used.

Option D-First and second generation cephalosporins(cefazolin) are the drugs of choice for preoperative prophylaxis for cardiac surgery. Preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis is essential in reducing the risk of surgical site infections.

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconscious with pulse and breathing present
Unconscious with pulse absent and breathing present.

questions.text: During resuscitation, when is the given position indicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Option A-CPR is done in Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent.

Option B-Breaths are given in cases of unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent.

Option C-The position illustrated in the picture is known as the recovery position, and it is used in the management of patients who are unconscious but with pulse present and breathing present.
Option D-Unconscious with pulse absent and breathing present,such scenarios do not happen.

questions.text: A child was brought with bony deformities as shown in the radiograph below. It could be due to the deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Option A-Vitamin A deficiency causes xerophthalmia.
Option B-The given paediatric radiograph depicts the bowing of legs, which occurs due to rickets that results from the deficiency of Vitamin D that results in poor mineralisation of bone leading to rickets in children and osteomalacia is adults.
Option C-Vitamin K deficiency results in bleeding disorders. Option D-Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy.

questions.text: In which of the following nerve injuries is the instrument shown below used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Option A-The image shown above is that of a cock-up splint. It is used to manage radial nerve palsy. Radial nerve palsy manifests as an inability to dorsiflex the wrist and digits (wrist drop and finger drop).
Option B-Median nerve injury causes carpal tunnel syndrome. Option C-knuckle bender splint is used in ulnar injury.
Option D-Turn buckle splint is used in Volkmanns ischemic contracture

choices.text: Bipartite fracture patella, X-ray of the other knee
Fracture of upper pole of patella, Cylindrical cast

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic knee pain but has no history of trauma. Identify the condition shown in the radiograph below and the appropriate management.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Option A-Patellar avulsion fracture do not have a smooth discontinuity.

Option B-The given X ray shows a patella with a smooth discontinuity suggestive of an unfused accessory ossification center. Since this should arouse the suspicion of a bipartite patella, appropriate management would be to take an X ray of the other knee to confirm the same on other side.
Option C,D-Fracture of upper pole of patella and Avulsion fracture also do not have a smooth discontinuity.

questions.text: A patient at the orthopedics OPD complains of troubled sleep at night due to numbness and tingling sensation involving his lateral 3 digits. His symptoms are relieved as he lays his arms hanging from the bed. Which amongst the following options correctly describes his condition along with the test used to assess it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The clinical vignette is suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome which is the most common entrapment mononeuropathy caused by compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel. Durkan’s test is the most specific test for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In Durkan’s test, direct median nerve compression for about 30 seconds, elicits paraesthesia and pain.
Guyons canal syndrome is due to compression of ulnar nerve for which froment test can be done.

questions.text: A child is brought to the orthopedics OPD with a deformity in the lower limb and hyperpigmented skin lesions. The xray of her thigh is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Option A-Non-ossifying fibroma do not present with hyperpigmented skin lesions.
Option B-The above Xray shows the bending of the femur known as Shepherd’s crook deformity. It is seen in fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur. Fibrous dysplasia is a condition that affects bone development and is characterised by the replacement of the bone with fibrous tissue. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia is associated with Albright-McCune syndrome.
Option C,D-Paget’s disease and Osteogenesis imperfecta do not present with hyperpigmented skin lesions.

questions.text: The given image is an xray of a 22-year-old female. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Option A-Chondroblastoma occurs in males of less than 18 years age.

Option B-Osteochondroma presents as a bony stalk covered by a cartilaginous cap.

Option C-The given X ray showing a lytic lesion at the end of a long bone with a soap bubble appearance suggests a giant cell tumor (GCT) or osteoclastoma. A GCT is a benign but locally aggressive tumor commonly occurring at the ends of long bones as a solitary lytic lesion in epiphysis.
Option D-Aneurysmal bone cyst mimic GCT but occurs in a younger age group

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Clotrimazole Explanation:
The patient is likely suffering from oral candidiasis (oral thrush), which is a common side effect in bronchial asthma patients using inhaled corticosteroids. Steroids can suppress local immunity in the oral cavity, making it easier for Candida species to overgrow.
Treatment:
Clotrimazole is a topical antifungal agent commonly used as a troche (lozenge) for local treatment of oral candidiasis.
It is effective against Candida albicans, the usual causative organism. Other options:
Griseofulvin: Effective against dermatophytes, not Candida. Not useful in oral candidiasis.

Terbinafine: Also mainly active against dermatophytes, not Candida.

Flucytosine: Used for systemic Candida or Cryptococcus infections, usually in serious invasive cases (often with amphotericin B), not for localized oral thrush.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with history of bronchial asthma is in the third stage of labour. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in this mother?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Carboprost Explanation:
In the management of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), uterotonic agents are used to contract the uterus and reduce bleeding. However, drug choice must consider patient-specific contraindications, such as bronchial asthma.
Carboprost (15-methyl PGF2α):
It is a prostaglandin F2α analogue.

While effective in controlling PPH, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction, which may trigger a life-threatening asthma attack.
Other options:
Oxytocin: First-line agent in PPH; safe in asthma.

Dinoprostone (PGE2 analogue): Can be used cautiously, though it may have mild bronchoconstrictive effects, it is generally considered safer than PGF2α analogues.
Methyl ergometrine: Contraindicated in hypertension, not asthma (use cautiously if coexisting conditions exist, but not absolutely contraindicated in asthma).

questions.text: Name the drug that inhibits both Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) and neural endopeptidase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Omapatrilat Explanation:
Omapatrilat is a drug that inhibits both:

Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE) – which converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor.
Neutral endopeptidase (also called neprilysin) – which breaks down natriuretic peptides like ANP and BNP that promote vasodilation and natriuresis.
Clinical Significance:
By inhibiting both enzymes, omapatrilat offers dual action: reducing vasoconstriction and enhancing vasodilation.
It was developed for use in heart failure and hypertension.

However, it was withdrawn from development due to a higher incidence of angioedema, likely because both ACE and neprilysin break down bradykinin — leading to its accumulation when both are inhibited.
Other options:
A.    Sacubitril: Inhibits neprilysin only. Often combined with valsartan (an ARB) in heart failure treatment.
B.    Losartan: An angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB); does not inhibit ACE or neprilysin.

C.    Nesiritide: A recombinant B-type natriuretic peptide, used in acute decompensated heart failure; it mimics but does not inhibit neprilysin or ACE.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for these side effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Amiodarone Explanation:
Amiodarone is a Class III antiarrhythmic drug commonly used for ventricular arrhythmias and atrial fibrillation. While it is effective, it has a notoriously long list of adverse effects due to its high iodine content and tendency to accumulate in tissues.
Key Side Effects of Amiodarone:
Pulmonary toxicity: Can cause pulmonary fibrosis, a serious and potentially fatal side effect. Thyroid dysfunction: Both hypo- and hyperthyroidism.
Hepatotoxicity

Skin changes: Photosensitivity, blue-gray skin discoloration. Neurologic symptoms: Tremor, ataxia, neuropathy.
Ocular toxicity
Cardiovascular effects: Bradycardia and hypotension. Patient Clues Matching Amiodarone Toxicity:
Fatigue, dyspnea, weight gain: Can indicate hypothyroidism or heart failure worsening. Pulmonary fibrosis: Classic and serious complication of long-term amiodarone therapy. History of MI and ventricular arrhythmia: Typical indication for starting amiodarone.
Why Not the Others?
Atenolol: Beta-blocker; may cause fatigue and bradycardia, but not pulmonary fibrosis.
Aspirin: Can cause GI bleeding or asthma exacerbation, not pulmonary fibrosis. Spironolactone: Can cause gynecomastia and hyperkalemia, not pulmonary fibrosis.

choices.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutamine stores
Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia
Sodium bicarbonate to alkalize the urine

questions.text: A young female comes to the emergency department after consuming 100 tablets of Aspirin. What should be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sodium bicarbonate to alkalize the urine Explanation:
The patient has likely experienced a salicylate (aspirin) overdose, which is a medical emergency. High doses of aspirin can lead to:
Metabolic acidosis (with increased anion gap)
Respiratory alkalosis (initially due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center) Tinnitus, nausea, vomiting, confusion, and even coma in severe toxicity Management of Aspirin Overdose:
The primary goals are to:

Reduce salicylate absorption Enhance salicylate elimination
Correct acid-base and fluid-electrolyte disturbances Key intervention:
Sodium bicarbonate: This is used to alkalinize the urine, which increases the ionized form of salicylate, reducing its reabsorption in the renal tubules and enhancing its excretion.
Urinary alkalinization is the cornerstone of treatment in moderate to severe salicylate poisoning. Why not the others?

A.    N-acetylcysteine: Used for paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose, not salicylates.

B.    Pralidoxime: Antidote for organophosphate poisoning, not aspirin.

C.    Glucagon: Used in beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker overdose, not aspirin.

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking deaddiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. What is the reason behind this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rebound hypertension Explanation:
Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in smoking cessation to help reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms. It works by inhibiting sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system, leading to decreased blood pressure and reduced symptoms of withdrawal.
However, abrupt discontinuation of clonidine can lead to a rebound increase in sympathetic tone. This can cause:
Rebound hypertension: A sudden increase in blood pressure due to the loss of the inhibitory effect of clonidine on sympathetic nervous activity.
Headache: A common symptom associated with rebound hypertension.

The mechanism behind rebound hypertension is the upregulation of alpha-1 receptors due to chronic clonidine use, and without the drug, the increased sympathetic activity causes a surge in blood pressure.
Why not the others?
A. Postural hypotension: Clonidine can cause hypotension when first started or in excessive doses, but rebound hypertension is more likely after discontinuation.
B. Receptor upregulation: While upregulation of receptors can occur with chronic clonidine use, the main issue after stopping the drug is rebound hypertension, not upregulation alone.
D. Receptor hypersensitivity: This term is more commonly used in reference to other conditions (e.g., beta-receptor hypersensitivity in asthma), but it’s not the best description of what occurs after stopping clonidine.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent attacks of gout was started on a therapy that inhibits the synthesis of uric acid. His symptoms were reduced after therapy. Which drug was he started on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Allopurinol Explanation:
Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that reduces the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which is involved in the conversion of purines to uric acid. It is the first-line therapy for chronic gout and is used to prevent recurrent gout attacks by lowering serum uric acid levels.

In gout, recurrent attacks occur due to elevated uric acid levels in the blood, which can crystallize and deposit in joints, causing inflammation. By inhibiting uric acid synthesis, allopurinol helps to prevent these attacks.
Why not the others?
A. Probenecid: This is a uricosuric agent that increases the excretion of uric acid by the kidneys, rather than inhibiting its production. It is used to manage gout in some cases but is not the drug of choice for reducing uric acid synthesis.
B. Colchicine: Colchicine is used to treat acute gout attacks by reducing inflammation. However, it does not lower uric acid levels or prevent recurrent attacks long-term.
D. Diclofenac: Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to reduce the inflammation and pain associated with acute gout attacks, but it does not affect uric acid production or prevent recurrent attacks.

questions.text: A patient with malignancy is undergoing chemotherapy. The platelet counts were reduced after the previous cycle of chemotherapy. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Oprelvekin (IL-11) Explanation:
Oprelvekin is an interleukin-11 (IL-11) analog that is used to stimulate platelet production in patients with chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia (low platelet count). Chemotherapy can lead to bone marrow suppression, reducing platelet production and increasing the risk of bleeding. Oprelvekin helps by promoting megakaryocyte development, which leads to increased platelet counts.
Why not the others?
B. Filgrastim: Filgrastim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) that stimulates the production of neutrophils (not platelets). It is used in cases of neutropenia (low white blood cell count), often after chemotherapy, but it does not address platelet deficiency.
C. Erythropoietin: Erythropoietin stimulates the production of red blood cells (RBCs), not platelets. It is used in conditions like anemia, particularly in chronic kidney disease or chemotherapy-induced anemia, but not for thrombocytopenia.
D. Amifostine: Amifostine is a cytoprotective agent used to reduce the toxic effects of chemotherapy, particularly for kidney protection in certain chemotherapy regimens, but it does not directly increase platelet production.

choices.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure
The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure.
The dose of candesartan should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure.
Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation

questions.text: The true statement among the following is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation Explanation:
Losartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) commonly used to treat hypertension and heart failure. In addition to its primary effect of blocking the angiotensin II receptor (AT1), it has also been shown to have a secondary effect as a thromboxane A2 antagonist. Thromboxane A2 promotes platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction, so by inhibiting this, losartan can reduce platelet aggregation, which might help in reducing the risk of thrombotic events.

Why not the others?
A.    The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure: This is incorrect. Telmisartan, like other ARBs, requires dose adjustment in renal failure but does not typically require dose reduction in hepatic failure unless the patient has severe liver impairment.
B.    The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure: This is incorrect. Irbesartan requires dose adjustment mainly in cases of severe renal failure. There is no need to reduce the dose in mild to moderate hepatic impairment unless there is severe hepatic dysfunction.
C.    The dose of candesartan should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure: This is incorrect. Candesartan should be adjusted in renal failure, especially in cases of severe renal dysfunction. It does not typically require dose adjustment in mild-moderate hepatic failure.

questions.text: A patient given digoxin started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4mg/dl. The plasma therapeutic range is 1mg/dl. If the half life of digoxin is 40 hours, how long should one wait before resuming the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

80 hours Explanation:
When a patient develops symptoms of digoxin toxicity (such as nausea and vomiting), the first step is to stop the medication. Digoxin has a long half-life (40 hours in this case), meaning it takes a long time for the drug to be eliminated from the body. The goal is to wait until the serum concentration of digoxin falls within the therapeutic range.

Key Points:
Therapeutic range of digoxin: 1 mg/dl. Current serum concentration: 4 mg/dl. Half-life of digoxin: 40 hours.
The general formula to estimate the time it will take for a drug to decrease to a safe concentration is:

Time to reach therapeutic level
= Half-life × log 2
( Current concentration Therapeutic concentration) Time to reach therapeutic level=Half-life×log
2 ( Therapeutic concentration Current concentration )
However, a simplified approach is to wait around 5 half-lives for a drug to drop close to a therapeutic range (for many drugs). This is because after 5 half-lives, the concentration typically falls by over 95%.
Calculation:
Given:

Half-life of digoxin = 40 hours
You would wait approximately 5 half-lives. 5 × 40 = 200 hours
5×40=200 hours
However, this calculation suggests an extended period. For clinical practicality and rapid therapeutic adjustment, a closer approximation is usually 2 half-lives for initial symptom resolution and then reassessment. Hence, 80 hours (which is 2 half-lives) is a reasonable estimate for when to reconsider therapy.

Why not the others?
A.    40 hours: This would only cover one half-life, not enough time for digoxin to reach therapeutic
levels.

C.    120 hours: While longer than necessary, this is an overestimate and unnecessary for most patients.
D.    140-180 hours: This is far too long and does not fit typical clinical guidelines for drug elimination.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with organophosphate poisoning. He was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the likely cause of fever?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Atropine toxicity Explanation:
Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist commonly used to treat organophosphate poisoning, as it blocks the effects of excess acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors. However, atropine can have side effects, especially when given in large doses or as an infusion.
One of the known side effects of atropine is hyperthermia (fever). This can occur because:
Atropine reduces sweating (by inhibiting the parasympathetic nervous system), which leads to impaired heat dissipation.
It can also cause central nervous system effects, including altered thermoregulation.

In cases of organophosphate poisoning, atropine is given to counteract the muscarinic effects of the poisoning, but if too much atropine is used, toxic effects can result, including fever, dry mouth, blurred vision, and urinary retention.
Why not the others?
B.    Side effect of pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase and reverse the effects of organophosphate poisoning. It generally does not cause a significant rise in temperature.
C.    Due to organophosphate poisoning: While organophosphates can cause muscarinic effects like excessive salivation, bronchorrhea, and bradycardia, fever is more commonly due to atropine toxicity rather than the poisoning itself. Organophosphate poisoning leads to hypothermia in some cases due to excessive cholinergic stimulation, rather than fever.
D.    Idiopathic: While fever can sometimes occur without a clear cause, in this case, the administration of atropine strongly suggests that the fever is likely due to atropine toxicity.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Enhance fibrin degradation Explanation:
Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is a thrombolytic agent used to treat conditions like acute ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, and pulmonary embolism by promoting the breakdown of fibrin in blood clots. The mechanism of action of tPA involves the conversion of plasminogen (which is incorporated into clots) into plasmin, the enzyme that degrades fibrin, breaking down the clot.
Thus, tPA enhances fibrin degradation, leading to the dissolution of thrombi. Why not the others?
A. Inhibits extrinsic pathway: The extrinsic pathway of coagulation involves tissue factor and factor
VII, which initiates clotting. tPA does not directly inhibit the extrinsic pathway but works by promoting fibrinolysis (clot breakdown).
B. Inhibits platelet aggregation: While antiplatelet drugs like aspirin or clopidogrel inhibit platelet aggregation, tPA does not work by inhibiting platelet aggregation. Its action is centered around fibrinolysis.
D. Inhibit clot formation: tPA does not inhibit clot formation; instead, it promotes the breakdown of clots after they have formed.

questions.text: After eating an unknown plant, a child was presented to the emergency with comatose status. The pupil were dilated and skin was dry. Body temperature was raised and the heart rate was high. These signs and symptoms can occur with the intake of which of the following substance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dhatura Explanation:
The symptoms described in the question—dilated pupils, dry skin, elevated body temperature, and high heart rate—are consistent with anticholinergic toxicity. These symptoms are typically caused by the ingestion of substances that contain anticholinergic compounds.

Dhatura (Datura stramonium) is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties, which can cause delirium, hallucinations, dilated pupils, dry mouth, increased heart rate, elevated body temperature, and skin dryness. The alkaloids in dhatura (e.g., scopolamine, hyoscyamine) inhibit acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, leading to these characteristic toxic effects. In severe cases, dhatura poisoning can result in coma and death due to its systemic effects.

Why the other options are incorrect:
A.    Foxglove – Incorrect:

Foxglove (digitalis) contains compounds called cardiac glycosides, which primarily affect the heart by inhibiting the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to arrhythmias and bradycardia (slow heart rate), not symptoms like dry skin, elevated body temperature, or dilated pupils. The symptoms described are more characteristic of anticholinergic poisoning, not digitalis toxicity.
B.    Poppy seeds – Incorrect:

Poppy seeds contain trace amounts of opioid alkaloids (such as morphine and codeine), but they are not known to cause the anticholinergic symptoms of dilated pupils, dry skin, and elevated body temperature. Opioid toxicity would cause miosis (constricted pupils), respiratory depression, and bradycardia, not the signs mentioned in the question.
C.    Cannabinoid – Incorrect:

Cannabinoids (such as those found in marijuana) generally cause euphoria, drowsiness, increased heart rate, and conjunctival injection (red eyes), but they do not typically produce the anticholinergic symptoms described. While cannabinoid toxicity can lead to altered mental status, it does not typically cause dilated pupils and dry skin as seen with dhatura poisoning.

questions.text: A 36 week pregnant patient on warfarin. INR level is 3.Best Course of action would be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Stop warfarin and switch to heparin Explanation:
In a pregnant patient, warfarin is generally contraindicated, especially after the first trimester due to its teratogenic effects (it can cause fetal bleeding, cranial malformations, and other complications). Although the patient is currently on warfarin and has an INR of 3, which is within the therapeutic range for anticoagulation, warfarin should be discontinued immediately in pregnancy.
 
The best course of action in this case is to stop warfarin and switch to heparin, which is the preferred anticoagulant during pregnancy. Heparin (both unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin) does not cross the placenta and is safe for the fetus.
Additionally, heparin can provide adequate anticoagulation, and the patient's INR should be monitored while transitioning to heparin therapy.
Why the other options are incorrect:
A.    Add aspirin – Incorrect:

Aspirin is not typically used as a sole anticoagulant in pregnancy, particularly in this case, where the patient is on warfarin and has an elevated INR. Adding aspirin alone is not sufficient for anticoagulation, especially in patients requiring a more effective therapy for conditions like deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

B.    Aspirin + Heparin – Incorrect:

While heparin is appropriate for anticoagulation during pregnancy, adding aspirin is typically used in specific conditions like preeclampsia, recurrent pregnancy loss, or for antiplatelet effects in certain cardiovascular conditions. It is not needed in this case, and the priority should be stopping warfarin and starting heparin.

C.    Continue warfarin – Incorrect:

Continuing warfarin is not recommended during pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, due to the risk of fetal bleeding and teratogenicity. The best approach is to stop warfarin immediately and switch to heparin.

questions.text: For which of the following procedures in the given OT list, can you preferably do a hysteroscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Asherman syndrome Hysteroscopy is used for the definitive diagnosis of Asherman syndrome. Asherman syndrome refers to the presence of adhesion within the endometrial cavity. It is also called uterine synechiae. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous uterine curettage, tuberculous endometritis, pelvic radiation, or endometrial ablation.

questions.text: A 50 year old woman presents with foul smelling bloody discharge per vagina mixed with mucous. On examination, a necrotizing growth is seen in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. What is the management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Chemoradiation The patient with a cervical tumor involving the parametrium has stage 2B cervical carcinoma, which is treated primarily with chemoradiation. This involves the combination of external beam radiation therapy, brachytherapy, and chemotherapy.

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is set to undergo a complete laparoscopic hysterectomy. She wants to know if there are any disadvantages to this procedure. What are the disadvantages of laparoscopic over open surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Not knowing the extent of thermal burns Diathermy burns are a particular hazard in laparoscopic surgery due to: relative lack of visibility of the entire instrument, faulty insulation of laparoscopic instruments, intraperitoneal contact of the diathermy with another metal instrument while activating the pedal, etc

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of pain and swelling in the perineal area. She also has complains of difficulty in walking and sitting. She gives history of multiple sexual partners. On examination, a tender swelling is seen with redness on the labia, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bartholin abscess Bartholin glands are homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The function of the Bartholin gland is to secrete mucus for lubrication during coitus. Bartholin cyst is caused by obstruction of the duct due to infection, trauma, mucus changes and congenitally narrowed ducts. If the cyst gets infected, it leads to the formation of a Bartholin abscess.

choices.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.text: A 23 year old woman accompanied by her mother in law comes to the infertility clinic. She has been having regular intercourse for 6 months but is not able to conceive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The next best step would be to reassure and review the couple after 6 months. The inability to conceive after 1 year of unprotected intercourse is described as infertility. Infertility evaluation is offered to any couple that has failed to conceive after 1 year of regular unprotected intercourse.

questions.text: A 28 year old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of intermenstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Neisseria gonorrhoea Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by N. gonorrhoea. It uses pili in adhesion to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. The major symptoms include vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, ad dysuria.

questions.text: A 24 year old woman who is being treated for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin came with complaints of sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting and breathlessness. The finding of the ultrasound is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome The above sonogram shows enlarged ovaries having large cysts, seen in OHSS. OHSS is characterised by multiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It happens often as a complication of ovulation induction therapy for infertility. It occurs due to the stimulation of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by HCG.

questions.text: During a hysteroscopic removal of a submucosal fibroid, a fluid deficit of 2000ml is estimated in a patient. What is the immediate complication of this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pulmonary edema The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of fluid overload, and pulmonary edema is the immediate complication anticipated in this scenario. The term fluid deficit refers to the difference between the volume of distention fluid introduced into the uterine cavity and the volume of fluid that is removed during the procedure.

questions.text: A 54 year old woman was diagnosed with advanced cervical cancer. She has a 14 year old daughter. What advice would you give her daughter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Advise HPV vaccine The patient’s daughter is not at a higher risk for developing cervical cancer because it does not run in families. The etiology of cervical cancer is related to Human papilloma virus (HPV) infection, and immunization against the virus is protective.

questions.text: A 17 year old girl is seen for primary amenorrhea. There is no development of breasts or hair in the pubic or axillary region. Her height is 155cm and her weight is 48kg. She has bilateral inguinal masses. On USG examination, the uterus, fallopian tube, and ovary are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS) occurs in individuals with a 46,XY karyotype who are resistant to androgens due to a defective androgen receptor. As a result, although they produce normal levels of testosterone and anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH), their tissues cannot respond to androgens. AMH causes regression of Müllerian structures, so the uterus and fallopian tubes are absent. Externally, they appear female but lack pubic and axillary hair due to androgen insensitivity. Testes are present and often found as inguinal masses. Breast development can vary but is often present due to peripheral aromatization of testosterone to estrogen. The presence of inguinal masses, absent uterus and ovaries, and lack of pubic hair makes CAIS the most likely diagnosis. Option B: Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism (Incorrect) In hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, such as in gonadal dysgenesis, there is failure of the gonads to respond to gonadotropins, resulting in elevated FSH and LH levels. These patients typically have a uterus and fallopian tubes because there is no AMH production. While they may have primary amenorrhea and absent breast development, the presence of a uterus and lack of inguinal masses differentiates this from CAIS. The complete absence of Müllerian structures and presence of testes in the inguinal region rule out this diagnosis. Option C: Turner Syndrome (Incorrect) Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45,X karyotype and is typically associated with short stature, primary amenorrhea, and streak ovaries. Patients with Turner syndrome always have a uterus because they lack AMH production. They also usually develop normal pubic and axillary hair, as adrenal androgens are unaffected. The patient in this case is of normal height and has no uterus or ovaries, which is not consistent with Turner syndrome. Option D: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (Incorrect) PCOS is a condition seen in individuals with normal female internal anatomy and is associated with hyperandrogenism, menstrual irregularity, and polycystic ovaries. These patients typically have a uterus and ovaries, develop secondary sexual characteristics, and may have excess pubic an axillary hair rather than a complete absence. Since the patient lacks internal female organs and secondary sexual features, PCOS is not a plausible diagnosis.

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with cyclical pelvic pain every month. She has not achieved menarche yet. On examination, a suprapubic bulge can be seen in the lower abdomen. PR examination reveals a bulging swelling in the anterior aspect. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Imperforate hymen The given case scenario is suggestive of cryptomenorrhea due to an imperforate hymen. Cryptomenorrhea is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to ab obstruction of the outflow tract. The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. Patient presents with amenorrhea, cyclical abdominal pain, urinary symptoms and a hypogastric lump on abdominal examination. A bluish bulging membrane at the vaginal opening is noted on genital examination and the Valsalva maneuver.

questions.text: A partogram of a woman who is in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion is already given. How will you manage the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Caesarean section Based on the above partogram, there is a cephalopelvic disproportion, and the management in this case would be to do an emergency cesarian section. The patient has adequate uterine contractions. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium, and there is a fall in fetal heart rate, which indicates that the baby is in distress. This shows that there is an arrest of the fetal head with molding, which points to cephalopelvic disproportion.

questions.text: A woman presents to you at 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distention. Fetal movements are normal. On examination, fetal parts are not easily felt and fetal heartbeat is heard but it is muﬄed. Her symphysis fundal height is 41cm. Her abdomen is tense but not tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Polyhydramnios The diagnosis in this case in which symphysis fundal height is 41cm at 36 weeks of gestation and the woman presents with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distention is most likely Polyhydramnios. Polyhydramnios can be defined as the presence of excessive amniotic fluid, which exceeds 2L. The sonographic diagnosis of polyhydramnios can be given as AFI>25cm, DVP>8cm.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you with anemia early in her pregnancy. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her hemoglobin level is 9g/dl. When should the iron supplements be started for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

8 to 10 weeks The pregnant mother is said to be anemic when the level of haemoglobin is less than 11g/dl in the first and third trimesters and less than 10.5g/dl in the second trimester. Anaemia in the first trimester is treated by oral iron therapy. If a pregnant woman is found to be anemic, the iron supplementation should be started as soon as the anemia is diagnosed, regardless of gestational age. Early diagnosis and treatment of anemia are crucial to reduce the risk of complications for both the mother and the baby.

questions.text: A female presents to with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaining of bleeding per vagina and slight abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive and hCG level is 2800 IU/L. A mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3x2.5cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Single-dose methotrexate injection The clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of unruptured ectopic pregnancy. Medical management is preferred in the following cases:
1. Low initial serum beta HCG level (<5000IU/L) 2. Small ectopic pregnancy size (Less than 3.5cm) 3. Absent fetal cardiac activity 4. Hemodynamically stable The medical management consists of an im 50mg/m2 BSA methotrexate injection.

questions.text: A 27 year old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presents to you at 36+6 weeks. Ultrasound is done and shows the foetus in a transverse lie The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no risk factors. Both her previous deliveries were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A transverse lie occurs when the fetal long axis is perpendicular to the maternal spine, with the fetal shoulder often presenting. This position is incompatible with vaginal delivery, and management depends on gestational age, labor status, and maternal-fetal condition. Management Steps: 1. Confirm Diagnosis: • Clinical examination: Palpation of fetal position and Leopold maneuvers. • Ultrasound: Confirm transverse lie and assess placental location, amniotic fluid, and fetal anomalies. 2. Assess Factors: • Parity: Transverse lie is more common in multiparous women due to lax uterine tone. • Placental location: Associated with placenta previa. • Amniotic fluid volume: Polyhydramnios increases mobility, while oligohydramnios may fix the fetus in this position.
3. Management Options: • Before Labor: • External Cephalic Version (ECV): • Performed after 37 weeks if no contraindications. • Success depends on uterine tone and amniotic fluid volume. • If ECV is unsuccessful, plan for cesarean delivery. • In Labor: • Cesarean Section: • The definitive mode of delivery for persistent transverse lie. • Immediate cesarean is required if labor starts or membranes rupture to prevent complications (e.g., cord prolapse, uterine rupture). • Attempt ECV: Sometimes attempted early in labor if membranes are intact and no contraindications exist. 4. Contraindications to ECV: • Placenta previa. • Oligohydramnios. • Uterine abnormalities (e.g., fibroids, uterine scars). • Fetal distress or anomalies. 5. Complications to Watch For: • Cord Prolapse: Common in transverse lie when membranes rupture. • Uterine Rupture: Increased risk in multiparous women or if labor progresses.

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.text: A woman presents to you at 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back. She says she feels alright if she lies on her side or when she walks. What is the most likely reason behind this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

IVC compression The most likely reason a woman at 36 weeks of gestation complains of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back but feels alright when she lies on her side or walks is inferior vena cava (IVC) compression. When the patient is supine during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus has a compressive effect on the IVC. This results in opening up collateral circulation through the means of paravertebral and azygos veins. However, is some cases, the collateral circulation is unable to open up, and the heart’s venous return may get severely impaired. Syncope, tachycardia, and hypotension are produced as a result. This phenomenon is called supine hypotension syndrome (postural hypotension).

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. The x-ray image is given below. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cephalhematoma Cephalhematoma is a collection of blood in between the pericranium and the flat bone (subperiosteal) of the skull, usually unilateral and over a parietal bone. It is never present at birth but gradually develops after 12-24 hours. The swelling is limited by suture lines of the skull as the pericranium is fixed to the margins of the bone.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, and the x-ray showed the following features. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Putty kidney Putty kidney is the characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis, specifically renal TB. The given image shows a homogenous and ground-like calcification of the kidney appearing like a putty. It is caused by a dissemination of the organism through the blood stream and is thus always a secondary TB.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant.
Small intestinal mucosa is most radioresistant.

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source Radiotherapy is a common treatment modality for various cancers. It works by targeting rapidly dividing cancer cells with ionizing radiation, which can damage the DNA of these cells and lead to cell death. Larger blood vessels are more radioresistant than microvasculature. Premature non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells Small intestinal epithelial cells which divide rapidly with no differentiation are the most radiosensitive.

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of fever and cough for the past 3-5 days. His examination findings findings reveal crepitations. Chest xray is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The chest xray shows opacities with obscuration of the right cardiac border is suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation. The loss of clear demarcation between the normal lung and its surrounding soft structures is called the silhouette sign. It occurs due to loss of contrast between lungs and soft tissue when the lung parenchyma is no longer filled with air.x

questions.text: A newborn presented with chest retractions, dyspnea and lethargy. The pediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to deficiency of-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in newborns, particularly preterm infants, occurs due to the deficiency of surfactant, which reduces surface tension in the alveoli, preventing their collapse. The primary component of surfactant is lecithin, specifically dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) Other options: Dipalmitoyl inositol: Not a surfactant component Sphingomyelin: Present in the lungs but does not contribute significantly to reducing alveolar surface tension Dipalmitoylphosphatidylethanolamine: Another phospholipid but not a major surfactant component

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 20ml/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20ml/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10ml/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10ml/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.text: A 10 year old child weighing 30kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations were as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? RBS- 550 mg/dl pH- 7.01 Na+- 158mEq/L Urine glucose- 3+
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This child presents with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is characterized by severe dehydration, hyperglycemia (RBS 550 mg/dL), metabolic acidosis (pH 7.01), and glucosuria. The initial management focuses on stabilizing the child by addressing dehydration and restoring perfusion. The correct initial approach is managing ABC, giving NS 20 ml/kg bolus, and delaying insulin administration by 1 hour (Option A). This ensures safe and effective management of severe dehydration and DKA Other options: Option B: Starting insulin along with NS bolus may increase the risk of cerebral edema due to rapid shifts in osmolality Option C & D: A 10 ml/kg bolus is insufficient in severe dehydration and may not adequately restore perfusion

choices.text: Increase in length 25cm in the first year
Weight gain of 300g per month till 1 year
Anterior frontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.text: Which of the following is the best sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 2.8kg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increase in length: Infants usually grow around 25 cm in length during the first year. This reflects normal physical growth, as their bones and body structure expand significantly Other options: Weight gain: Infants are expected to double their birth weight by 4-6 months and triple it by 12 months. A weight gain of 300 g per month is typical but not as specific an indicator of overall growth compared to length Fontanelle closure: The anterior fontanelle generally closes around 18-24 months, not necessarily by 6 months. Its closure is not a reliable sign of adequate growth during the first year Weight and height percentiles: Being below the 75th percentile for weight or the 25th percentile for height does not necessarily indicate inadequate growth unless there is a concern about failure to thrive or growth delay

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. The radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The diagnosis is most likely acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup), characterized by respiratory distress, biphasic stridor, and the characteristic steeple sign on radiograph (Option B) Other options: A) Acute epiglottitis: This condition involves severe upper airway obstruction and is associated with drooling, dysphagia, and a tripod position. It usually does not present with the steeple sign; instead, it may show thickening of the epiglottis (thumbprint sign) on radiograph C) Foreign body aspiration: This is typically characterized by sudden onset of coughing, wheezing, and unilateral wheezing. A radiograph may show signs of the foreign body (e.g., aspiration of a coin or other object), but it would not cause the classic steeple sign D) Laryngomalacia: This is a congenital condition that leads to stridor in infants, but it is usually not associated with an acute infection and would not present with a steeple sign on a radiograph

questions.text: A 3 month old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The most likely diagnosis is congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), which presents with the characteristic triad of deafness, cataracts, and PDA (Option D) Other options: A) Congenital Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV): HSV infection in newborns can lead to skin lesions, encephalitis, or disseminated infection but does not typically present with deafness, cataracts, and PDA. It may cause neonatal encephalitis or skin and eye lesions but is less likely to be associated with the triad seen in this case B) Congenital Toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis can cause chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus but does not usually present with the triad of deafness, cataracts, and PDA C) Congenital CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Congenital CMV infection can cause sensorineural hearing loss, microcephaly, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications, but PDA is not a characteristic feature. Cataracts are also less commonly seen in congenital CMV compared to rubella

questions.text: Chloride level in sweat is used in the diagnosis of which disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The sweat chloride test is used to diagnose cystic fibrosis (CF). This test measures the level of chloride in sweat, as elevated levels of chloride are characteristic of CF Other options: A) PKU (Phenylketonuria): PKU is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to an accumulation of phenylalanine in the blood. It is diagnosed through blood tests measuring phenylalanine levels, not through a sweat chloride test C) Gaucher Disease: Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder due to a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. It is diagnosed through enzyme activity tests in blood, not sweat chloride levels
D) Osteogenesis Imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic condition characterized by brittle bones due to a collagen synthesis defect. It is diagnosed through clinical evaluation and genetic testing, not through sweat chloride levels

questions.text: A 3 month old baby presents with jaundice and clay coloured stools. Lab investigation reveals that the baby has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The liver biopsy shows periductal proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The most likely diagnosis for a 3-month-old baby with jaundice, clay- colored stools, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and periductal proliferation on liver biopsy is biliary atresia Other options: A) Crigler-Najjar Syndrome: This is a rare disorder of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by a deficiency in UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. The jaundice in Crigler- Najjar is typically unconjugated, not conjugated, and it doesn't cause clay-colored stools or periductal proliferation on liver biopsy B) Rotor Syndrome: Rotor syndrome is a mild condition causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but without the characteristic bile duct abnormalities seen in biliary atresia. It usually presents with mild jaundice and doesn't result in clay-colored stools or liver biopsy findings of periductal proliferation C) Dubin-Johnson Syndrome: This is another disorder causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to a defect in the bilirubin transport mechanism. However, it typically presents with dark liver discoloration on imaging, which is not mentioned here, and doesn't result in periductal proliferation seen in biliary atresia.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and a rash spreading from the face, behind cheeks, and buccal mucosa to other body parts. On examination, Koplik’s spot is present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The child described with fever, rash spreading from face to other body parts, and the presence of Koplik spots is most likely suffering from measles Other options: B) Rubella: Rubella also causes a rash but it tends to be less severe and usually begins on the face and spreads downward. Koplik spots are not seen in rubella C) Varicella: Varicella (chickenpox) presents with a vesicular rash that begins on the trunk and scalp and spreads outward. It is different from the maculopapular rash seen in measles and does not have Koplik spots D) Mumps: Mumps primarily causes parotitis (swelling of the salivary glands) and does not typically cause the Koplik spots or rash associated with measles

questions.text: An infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Neuroimaging with CT shows periventricular calcifications. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The combination of hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, and periventricular calcifications on imaging in an infant is highly suggestive of congenital CMV (Cytomegalovirus) infection Other options: A) Congenital Rubella: While congenital rubella can present with hepatosplenomegaly, it typically also involves other signs like cataracts, heart defects, and sensorineural deafness, but periventricular calcifications are not characteristic B) Congenital HSV: Congenital HSV typically presents with skin lesions, neurodevelopmental impairment, and encephalitis but not the combination of hepatosplenomegaly and periventricular calcifications. It can cause severe neurological damage, but its presentation is usually different from CMV C) Congenital Toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis can cause hepatosplenomegaly and periventricular calcifications, but the thrombocytopenia is not as prominent, and the presence of calcifications alone is less specific for toxoplasmosis compared to CMV

questions.text: A 3 week old infant presents with cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. The total leucocyte count is >50,000 cells/microL. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The description of a 3-week-old infant presenting with paroxysms of cough followed by apnoea suggests the likely diagnosis of whooping cough (pertussis), caused by Bordetella. For a 3-week-old infant with suspected pertussis, azithromycin (A) is the appropriate antibiotic choice Other options: B) Amoxicillin: While amoxicillin is effective against a broad range of bacteria, it is not effective against Bordetella pertussis, which causes whooping cough. This makes it inappropriate for this case C) Cotrimoxazole: Cotrimoxazole (a combination of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole) is generally used for other bacterial infections, but it is not the first choice for treating whooping cough. It is less effective than macrolides D) Clarithromycin: Clarithromycin is another macrolide antibiotic that can treat Bordetella pertussis, but azithromycin is typically preferred due to its once-daily dosing and fewer side effects in infants

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with verrucous carcinoma around the glans of the penis. Examination reveals that the inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Partial penectomy
Partial penectomy is the most appropriate management for a patient with verrucous carcinoma (a type of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma) around the glans of the penis, especially when there is no involvement of the inguinal lymph nodes. Verrucous carcinoma has a slow-growing, locally invasive nature and rarely metastasizes to regional lymph nodes. The goal of treatment is to remove the tumor while preserving as much of the penis as possible to maintain function and appearance. Partial penectomy allows for complete excision of the tumor while sparing the healthy portion of the penis, making it the most appropriate surgical option in this scenario.
A.    Total penectomy – Total penectomy involves the complete removal of the penis and is typically reserved for cases where the tumor is extensive or involves critical structures that cannot be preserved. Since this patient has localized verrucous carcinoma and no involvement of the inguinal lymph nodes, total penectomy is too radical for this case.
B.    CO2 laser excision – CO2 laser excision is used for early-stage penile cancers and for lesions that are superficial and localized. However, in the case of verrucous carcinoma, the tumor may have a deep involvement of the penile tissue, which makes complete excision with a laser challenging. Laser therapy is not the first-line treatment for this condition if more extensive excision is required.
C.    Topical 5-fluorouracil – Topical 5-fluorouracil is used for superficial lesions, often in cases of pre- cancerous conditions like Bowen’s disease or actinic keratosis. However, verrucous carcinoma is usually a more invasive tumor, and the topical treatment would not provide sufficient tumor control in this case. Systemic treatment or more invasive surgery like partial penectomy is usually required for such lesions.

choices.text: Intraosseous route access for giving IV fluids

questions.text: Identify the procedure being performed in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intraosseous route access for giving IV fluids
The procedure shown in the image is intraosseous (IO) access, which is commonly used for the rapid administration of IV fluids, blood products, and medications when traditional intravenous (IV) access is difficult or impossible, particularly in emergency or resuscitation settings. The IO route involves inserting a specialized needle into the medullary cavity of a long bone (commonly the proximal tibia or humerus), which provides a non-collapsible venous access. This method is lifesaving in critically ill patients, especially children, where vascular collapse may make peripheral IV access challenging.
A. Intraosseous cannula for pain relief – This option is incorrect. While intraosseous access can be used to administer analgesics, it is not typically placed specifically for pain relief. The primary indication is emergency vascular access for fluid and drug delivery.
B. Bone marrow aspiration – This involves using a different technique and equipment to obtain bone marrow samples for diagnostic purposes, usually from the iliac crest. It is a more deliberate, sterile, and diagnostic procedure, not an emergency vascular access technique.
D. Intraosseous abscess drainage – This option refers to a surgical intervention for draining pus from an infected bone, such as in osteomyelitis, and is not related to the emergency access method shown in the image.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden onset perineal pain. O examination, foul smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection
The condition described—sudden onset perineal pain, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue in a diabetic patient—is consistent with Fournier's gangrene, a form of necrotizing fasciitis affecting the perineum and genital region. Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive, life-threatening soft tissue infection that is polymicrobial, involving a mixed infection of aerobic and anaerobic organisms. Common pathogens include E. coli, Klebsiella, Streptococcus, Bacteroides, and Clostridium species. These organisms synergistically lead to tissue destruction, gas formation, and systemic toxicity. Early diagnosis, broad-spectrum antibiotics targeting both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, and urgent surgical debridement are critical for survival.
A.    Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases – This is incorrect. Anti-gas gangrene serum (antitoxin against Clostridium perfringens) is specific to clostridial myonecrosis, not routinely used in Fournier’s gangrene, which is usually polymicrobial and not always caused by clostridia.
B.    Urinary diversion is the next step – This is not universally true. Urinary diversion, such as suprapubic catheterization, may be required only if the urethra is involved or access is compromised, but it is not the next immediate step. Emergency surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics take priority.
C.    Bilateral orchidectomy must be done – This is incorrect as well. Testes usually have a separate arterial supply from the testicular arteries (from the abdominal aorta), and may remain viable even when the scrotal wall is necrotic. Orchidectomy is only done if the testes are necrotic, not routinely.

choices.text: Parasympathetic- bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation
Sympathetic- retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction
Sympathetic- impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication following ligation of the first vessel during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sympathetic – retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction

The most common complication following ligation of the first vessel (usually the inferior mesenteric artery) during abdominoperineal resection (APR) for rectal carcinoma is damage to the sympathetic nerves, particularly the hypogastric plexus, which lie in close proximity to the vessel. These nerves are responsible for bladder neck closure and ejaculation mechanisms. Damage to these sympathetic fibers can result in retrograde ejaculation (where semen enters the bladder instead of being expelled) and bladder dysfunction, particularly issues with bladder emptying. This complication arises due to the disruption of sympathetic innervation, which plays a crucial role in involuntary control of urinary and reproductive functions.
A. Parasympathetic – bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation – This is incorrect because parasympathetic nerves (from the pelvic splanchnic nerves) are more involved in bladder contraction and erection, not bladder neck closure or ejaculation. Parasympathetic injury more commonly leads to issues with bladder emptying and erectile dysfunction, not retrograde ejaculation.
B. Sympathetic – bladder dysfunction and impotence – While bladder dysfunction can be due to sympathetic damage, impotence (erectile dysfunction) is primarily mediated by parasympathetic nerves. Therefore, this combination doesn't correctly match the nerve supply affected.
D. Sympathetic – impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region – This is incorrect because cutaneous sensation in the perineum is primarily supplied by somatic nerves (pudendal nerve), and impotence is more linked to parasympathetic damage, not sympathetic injury alone.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with the lesion given in the image. He had a traumatic injury to the chest one year ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Keloid
The most likely diagnosis is keloid, which is a benign fibroproliferative growth characterized by the excessive formation of scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound. In this case, the patient has a history of trauma to the chest, and the lesion appears as a raised, firm, nodular mass that has persisted and possibly enlarged over time — classic features of a keloid. Keloids are more common on areas such as the chest, shoulders, upper back, and earlobes, and tend to occur after skin trauma such as surgery, injury, burns, or acne. They often appear shiny and smooth and do not regress spontaneously. The delayed presentation and progressive growth of the lesion support the diagnosis.
A. Hemangioma – Incorrect. Hemangiomas are vascular tumors seen more commonly in infants and young children. They usually appear as soft, compressible, red or bluish lesions and are not associated with prior trauma. Additionally, they tend to involute over time, unlike keloids.
B. Hypertrophic scar – Incorrect. While hypertrophic scars also form after trauma, they are confined to the borders of the original wound and often regress over time. In contrast, keloids grow beyond the wound margins and persist or enlarge, as seen in this case.
D. Neurofibroma – Incorrect. Neurofibromas are nerve sheath tumors associated with neurofibromatosis, usually presenting as soft, skin-colored nodules that may be pedunculated. They are not typically linked with trauma and do not have the dense, fibrotic appearance seen in keloids.

questions.text: A 45 year old male underwent bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh (LCNT), also known as the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, is commonly at risk of entrapment during laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair, especially with mesh fixation or trocar placement near the anterior superior iliac spine. Entrapment of this nerve leads to a condition called meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain, burning, or numbness over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. Since this nerve is purely sensory, there is no motor weakness. The symptoms described in the patient are classic for LCNT entrapment post-hernia repair.
A.    Ilioinguinal nerve – Incorrect. The ilioinguinal nerve supplies the skin of the superomedial thigh, root of the penis/scrotum (in males), or mons pubis/labia majora (in females). Entrapment of this nerve would typically cause groin or scrotal pain, not lateral thigh pain.
B.    Iliohypogastric nerve – Incorrect. This nerve provides sensation over the lower abdominal wall and upper gluteal region. Entrapment would lead to suprapubic or flank pain, not pain isolated to the lateral thigh.
C.    Femoral nerve – Incorrect. The femoral nerve innervates the anterior thigh muscles (motor) and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. Entrapment of this nerve would cause motor weakness of hip flexion and knee extension, along with sensory loss, not isolated sensory pain on the lateral thigh.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

E2V3M4
